**Zagreb** ([/ˈzɑːɡrɛb/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [*ZAH-greb*](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling key")^[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)^
Croatian: [\[zǎːɡreb\]](/wiki/Help:IPA/Serbo-Croatian "Help:IPA/Serbo-Croatian") [](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/4/42/Hr-Zagreb.ogg/Hr-Zagreb.ogg.mp3 "Play audio")^[ⓘ](/wiki/File:Hr-Zagreb.ogg "File:Hr-Zagreb.ogg")^^[\[a\]](#cite_note-9)^)^[\[9\]](#cite_note-10)^ is the [capital](/wiki/Capital_(political) "Capital (political)") and [largest city](/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Croatia#List_of_cities_and_towns "List of cities and towns in Croatia") of [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia "Croatia").^[\[10\]](#cite_note-11)^ It is in the [north of the country](/wiki/Northern_Croatia "Northern Croatia"), along the [Sava](/wiki/Sava "Sava") river, at the southern slopes of the [Medvednica](/wiki/Medvednica "Medvednica") mountain. Zagreb stands near the international border between Croatia and [Slovenia](/wiki/Slovenia "Slovenia") at an elevation of approximately 158 m (518 ft) [above sea level](/wiki/Above_mean_sea_level "Above mean sea level").^[\[11\]](#cite_note-12)^ At the 2021 census, the city itself had a population of 767,131,^[\[3\]](#cite_note-Census_2021-3)^ while the population of [Zagreb metropolitan area](/wiki/Zagreb_metropolitan_area "Zagreb metropolitan area") is 1,086,528.{#cite_ref-Census_2021_3-1}

The oldest settlement in the vicinity of the city was the Roman [Andautonia](/wiki/Andautonia "Andautonia"), in today's [Šćitarjevo](/wiki/%C5%A0%C4%87itarjevo "Šćitarjevo").^[\[12\]](#cite_note-13)^ The historical record of the name "Zagreb" dates from 1134, in reference to the foundation of the settlement at [Kaptol](/wiki/Kaptol,_Zagreb "Kaptol, Zagreb") in 1094. Zagreb became a [free royal city](/wiki/Free_royal_city "Free royal city") in 1242.^[\[13\]](#cite_note-14)^ In 1851, [Janko Kamauf](/wiki/Janko_Kamauf "Janko Kamauf") became Zagreb's [first mayor](/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Zagreb "List of mayors of Zagreb").^[\[14\]](#cite_note-15)^ Zagreb has special status as a [Croatian administrative division](/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Croatia "Administrative divisions of Croatia")---it comprises a consolidated city-county (but separate from [Zagreb County](/wiki/Zagreb_County "Zagreb County")),^[\[15\]](#cite_note-16)^ and is administratively subdivided into [17 city districts](#City_districts).^[\[16\]](#cite_note-17)^ Most of the city districts lie at a low elevation along the [valley of the river Sava](/wiki/Posavina "Posavina"), but northern and northeastern city districts, such as [Podsljeme](/wiki/Podsljeme "Podsljeme")^[\[17\]](#cite_note-18)^ and [Sesvete](/wiki/Sesvete "Sesvete")^[\[18\]](#cite_note-19)^ districts are situated in the foothills of the [Medvednica](/wiki/Medvednica "Medvednica") mountain,^[\[19\]](#cite_note-20)^ making the city's geographical image quite diverse. The city extends over 30 km (19 mi) east-west and around 20 km (12 mi) north-south.^[\[20\]](#cite_note-21)^^[\[21\]](#cite_note-22)^ Zagreb ranks as a [global city](/wiki/Global_city "Global city"), with a 'Beta-' rating from the [Globalization and World Cities Research Network](/wiki/Globalization_and_World_Cities_Research_Network "Globalization and World Cities Research Network").^[\[22\]](#cite_note-23)^{#cite_ref-23}

The transport connections, the concentration of industry, scientific, and research institutions and industrial tradition underlie its leading economic position in Croatia.^[\[23\]](#cite_note-24)^^[\[24\]](#cite_note-25)^^[\[25\]](#cite_note-26)^ Zagreb is the seat of the [central government](/wiki/Central_government "Central government"), [administrative bodies](/wiki/Public_administration "Public administration"), and almost all [government ministries](/wiki/Government_of_Croatia "Government of Croatia").^[\[26\]](#cite_note-27)^^[\[27\]](#cite_note-28)^^[\[28\]](#cite_note-29)^ Almost all of the [largest Croatian companies](/wiki/List_of_Croatian_companies "List of Croatian companies"), [media](/wiki/Mass_media "Mass media"), and scientific institutions have their headquarters in the city. Zagreb is the most important transport hub in Croatia: here [Central Europe](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe"), the Mediterranean and [Southeast Europe](/wiki/Southeast_Europe "Southeast Europe") meet, making the Zagreb area the centre of the road, rail and air networks of [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia "Croatia"). It is a city known for its diverse economy, high [quality of living](/wiki/Quality_of_living "Quality of living"), [museums](#Museums), sporting, and entertainment events. Major branches of Zagreb's economy include [high-tech](/wiki/High-tech "High-tech") industries and the [service sector](/wiki/Service_sector "Service sector").{#cite_ref-29}  

Name {#Name}
------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Name")\]

The etymology of the name *Zagreb* is unclear. It was used for the united city only from 1852, but it had been in use as the name of the [Zagreb Diocese](/wiki/Zagreb_bishopric "Zagreb bishopric") since the 12th century and was increasingly used for the city in the 17th century.^[\[29\]](#cite_note-30)^ The name is first recorded in a charter by [Felician, Archbishop of Esztergom](/wiki/Felician,_Archbishop_of_Esztergom "Felician, Archbishop of Esztergom"), dated 1134, mentioned as *Zagrabiensem episcopatum*.^[\[30\]](#cite_note-31)^{#cite_ref-31}

The name is probably derived from Proto-Slavic word [\**grębъ*](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Reconstruction:Proto-Slavic/gr%C4%99b%D1%8A "wikt:Reconstruction:Proto-Slavic/grębъ") which means "hill" or "uplift". An Old Croatian reconstructed name [\**Zagrębъ*](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Reconstruction:Proto-Slavic/Zagr%C4%99b%D1%8A "wikt:Reconstruction:Proto-Slavic/Zagrębъ") is manifested through the city's former German name, **Agram** .^[\[31\]](#cite_note-Gluhak_1999-32)^ Some linguists (*e.g.* [Nada Klaić](/wiki/Nada_Klai%C4%87 "Nada Klaić"), [Miroslav Kravar](/w/index.php?title=Miroslav_Kravar&action=edit&redlink=1 "Miroslav Kravar (page does not exist)")) propose a [metathesis](/wiki/Metathesis_(linguistics) "Metathesis (linguistics)") of \**Zabreg* , which would originate from Old Slavic *breg* (see Proto-Slavic [\**bergъ*](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Reconstruction:Proto-Slavic/berg%D1%8A "wikt:Reconstruction:Proto-Slavic/bergъ")) in the sense of "riverbank", referring to River Sava. This metathesis has been attested in [Kajkavian](/wiki/Kajkavian "Kajkavian"),^[\[32\]](#cite_note-Gračanin_2012-33)^ but the meaning of "riverbank" is lost in modern Croatian and [folk etymology](/wiki/Folk_etymology "Folk etymology") associates it instead with *breg* "hill", ostensibly referring to Medvednica. Hungarian linguist Gyula Décsy similarly uses metathesis to construct \**Chaprakov(o)* , a putative Slavicisation of a Hungarian [hypocorism](/wiki/Hypocorism "Hypocorism") for "[Cyprian](/wiki/Cyprian "Cyprian")", similar to the etymology of [Csepreg](/wiki/Csepreg "Csepreg"), Hungary.^[\[33\]](#cite_note-Desy1990-34)^ The most likely derivation is \**Zagrębъ* in the sense of "embankment" or "rampart", *i.e.* remains of the 1st millennium fortifications on [Grič](/wiki/Gradec,_Zagreb "Gradec, Zagreb").^[\[32\]](#cite_note-Gračanin_2012-33)^^[\[31\]](#cite_note-Gluhak_1999-32)^{#cite_ref-Gluhak_1999_32-1}

In [Middle Latin](/wiki/Middle_Latin "Middle Latin") and [Modern Latin](/wiki/Neo-Latin "Neo-Latin"), Zagreb is known as *Agranum* (the name of an unrelated Arabian city in [Strabo](/wiki/Strabo "Strabo")),^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^ *Zagrabia* or *Mons Graecensis* (also *Mons Crecensis* , in reference to [Grič (Gradec)](/wiki/Gradec,_Zagreb "Gradec, Zagreb")).

The most common folk etymology of the name of the city has been from the verb stem *[za](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Reconstruction:Proto-Slavic/za "wikt:Reconstruction:Proto-Slavic/za")-[grab-](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Reconstruction:Proto-Slavic/grob%D1%8A "wikt:Reconstruction:Proto-Slavic/grobъ")* , meaning "to scoop" or "to dig". A folk legend illustrating this derivation, attested but discarded as a serious etymology by [Ivan Tkalčić](/wiki/Ivan_Tkal%C4%8Di%C4%87 "Ivan Tkalčić"), ties the name to a drought of the early 14th century, during which [Augustin Kažotić](/wiki/Augustin_Ka%C5%BEoti%C4%87 "Augustin Kažotić") (c. 1260--1323) is said to have dug a well which miraculously produced water.^[\[34\]](#cite_note-35)^ In another legend,^[\[35\]](#cite_note-36)^^[\[36\]](#cite_note-37)^^[\[37\]](#cite_note-38)^^[\[38\]](#cite_note-39)^^[\[39\]](#cite_note-40)^ a city governor is thirsty and orders a girl named Manda to "scoop" water from the [Manduševac](/wiki/Ban_Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87_Square#History "Ban Jelačić Square") well (nowadays a fountain in Ban Jelačić Square), using the imperative: *Zagrabi, Mando!* ("Scoop, Manda!").^[\[40\]](#cite_note-41)^{#cite_ref-41}  

History {#History}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=2 "Edit section: History")\]  
Main article: [History of Zagreb](/wiki/History_of_Zagreb "History of Zagreb")  
For a chronological guide, see [Timeline of Zagreb](/wiki/Timeline_of_Zagreb "Timeline of Zagreb").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Andautonia%2C_iskopine_starorimskog_naselja.jpg/200px-Andautonia%2C_iskopine_starorimskog_naselja.jpg)](/wiki/File:Andautonia,_iskopine_starorimskog_naselja.jpg) Ruins of the ancient Roman town [Andautonia](/wiki/Andautonia "Andautonia") near Zagreb

The oldest known settlement located near present-day Zagreb, the Roman town of [Andautonia](/wiki/Andautonia "Andautonia"), now [Ščitarjevo](/wiki/%C5%A0%C4%8Ditarjevo "Ščitarjevo"), existed between the 1st and the 5th centuries AD.^[\[41\]](#cite_note-andautonia-42)^{#cite_ref-andautonia_42-0}

The first recorded appearance of the name "Zagreb" dates from 1094, at which time the city existed as two different city centers: the smaller, eastern [Kaptol](/wiki/Kaptol,_Zagreb "Kaptol, Zagreb"), inhabited mainly by [clergy](/wiki/Clergy "Clergy") and housing [Zagreb Cathedral](/wiki/Zagreb_Cathedral "Zagreb Cathedral"), and the larger, western [Gradec](/wiki/Gradec,_Zagreb "Gradec, Zagreb"), inhabited mainly by craftsmen and merchants. In 1851 the [Ban of Croatia](/wiki/Ban_of_Croatia "Ban of Croatia"), [Josip Jelačić](/wiki/Josip_Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87 "Josip Jelačić"), united Gradec and Kaptol; the name of the main city square, [Ban Jelačić Square](/wiki/Ban_Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87_Square "Ban Jelačić Square") honors him.^[\[42\]](#cite_note-Ban_Josip_Jelačić-43)^{#cite_ref-Ban_Josip_Jelačić_43-0}

While Croatia formed part of [Yugoslavia](/wiki/Yugoslavia "Yugoslavia") (1918 to 1991), Zagreb remained an important economic centre of that country, and was the second largest city. After [Croatia declared independence](/wiki/Croatian_independence_referendum,_1991 "Croatian independence referendum, 1991") from Yugoslavia in 1991, the [Parliament of the Republic of Croatia](/wiki/Croatian_Parliament "Croatian Parliament") ([Croatian](/wiki/Croatian_language "Croatian language"): *Sabor Republike Hrvatske* ) proclaimed Zagreb as the capital of the Republic of Croatia.^[\[43\]](#cite_note-Sluzbeni_List-44)^{#cite_ref-Sluzbeni_List_44-0}  

### Early Zagreb {#Early_Zagreb}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Early Zagreb")\]

The history of Zagreb dates as far back as 1094 when the [Hungarian](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary "Kingdom of Hungary") [King Ladislaus](/wiki/Ladislaus_I_of_Hungary "Ladislaus I of Hungary"), returning from his campaign against the [Kingdom of Croatia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia_(medieval) "Kingdom of Croatia (medieval)"), founded a diocese. Alongside the bishop's [see](/wiki/Episcopal_see "Episcopal see"), the canonical settlement [Kaptol](/wiki/Kaptol,_Zagreb "Kaptol, Zagreb") developed north of [Zagreb Cathedral](/wiki/Zagreb_Cathedral "Zagreb Cathedral"), as did the fortified settlement [Gradec](/wiki/Gradec,_Zagreb "Gradec, Zagreb") on the neighbouring hill, with the border between the two formed by the Medveščak stream.^[\[44\]](#cite_note-45)^ Today the latter is Zagreb's Upper Town ([Gornji Grad](/wiki/Gornji_Grad_%E2%80%93_Medve%C5%A1%C4%8Dak "Gornji Grad – Medveščak")) and is one of the best-preserved urban nuclei in Croatia. Both settlements came under [Mongol](/wiki/Mongol_invasion_of_Europe "Mongol invasion of Europe") attack in 1242.^[\[45\]](#cite_note-46)^ As a sign of gratitude for offering him a safe haven from the Mongols, the Croatian and Hungarian [King Béla IV](/wiki/B%C3%A9la_IV_of_Hungary "Béla IV of Hungary") granted Gradec the [Golden Bull of 1242](/wiki/Golden_Bull_of_1242 "Golden Bull of 1242"), which gave its citizens exemption from county rule and autonomy, as well as their own [judicial system](/wiki/Judiciary "Judiciary").^[\[46\]](#cite_note-47)^^[\[47\]](#cite_note-48)^{#cite_ref-48}  

### The relationship between Kaptol and Gradec throughout history {#The_relationship_between_Kaptol_and_Gradec_throughout_history}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: The relationship between Kaptol and Gradec throughout history")\]

The development of Kaptol began in 1094 after the foundation of the [diocese](/wiki/Diocese "Diocese"), while the growth of Gradec began after the [Golden Bull](/wiki/Golden_Bull_of_1242 "Golden Bull of 1242") was issued in 1242. In the history of the city of Zagreb, there have been numerous conflicts between Gradec and Kaptol, mainly due to disputed issues of rent collection and due to disputed properties.

The first known conflicts took place in the middle of the 13th century and continued with interruptions until 1667. Because of the conflict, it was recorded that the Bishop of Kaptol excommunicated the residents of Gradec twice.

In the conflicts between Gradec and Kaptol, there were several massacres of the citizens, destruction of houses and looting of citizens. In 1850, Gradec and Kaptol, with surrounding settlements, were united into a single settlement, today's city of Zagreb.^[\[48\]](#cite_note-49)^^[\[49\]](#cite_note-50)^^[\[50\]](#cite_note-51)^^[\[51\]](#cite_note-52)^^[\[52\]](#cite_note-53)^{#cite_ref-53}  

### 16th to 18th centuries {#16th_to_18th_centuries}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: 16th to 18th centuries")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fa/Zagreb-Valvasor.jpg/200px-Zagreb-Valvasor.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zagreb-Valvasor.jpg) Modern Zagreb's town core emerged from the Upper Town [medieval](/wiki/Medieval "Medieval") settlements of [Gradec](/wiki/Gradec,_Zagreb "Gradec, Zagreb") and [Kaptol](/wiki/Kaptol,_Zagreb "Kaptol, Zagreb"). Picture from 1689.

There were numerous connections between the Kaptol diocese and the free sovereign town of Gradec for both economic and political reasons, but they were not known as an integrated city, even as Zagreb became the political center, and the regional Sabor ([Latin](/wiki/Latin_language "Latin language"): *Congregatio Regnorum Croatiae, Dalmatiae et Slavoniae* ) representing Croatia, [Slavonia](/wiki/Slavonia "Slavonia") and [Dalmatia](/wiki/Dalmatia "Dalmatia"), first convened at Gradec. Zagreb became the Croatian capital in 1557, with city also being chosen as the seat of the [Ban of Croatia](/wiki/Ban_of_Croatia "Ban of Croatia") in 1621 under ban [Nikola IX Frankopan](/wiki/Nikola_IX_Frankopan "Nikola IX Frankopan").^[\[53\]](#cite_note-54)^{#cite_ref-54}

At the invitation of the [Croatian Parliament](/wiki/Croatian_Parliament "Croatian Parliament"), the [Jesuits](/wiki/Society_of_Jesus "Society of Jesus") came to Zagreb and built the first [grammar school](/wiki/Grammar_school "Grammar school"),^[\[54\]](#cite_note-55)^ the [St. Catherine's](/wiki/Catherine_of_Alexandria "Catherine of Alexandria") Church (built 1620-1632^[\[55\]](#cite_note-56)^) and monastery. In 1669, they founded an academy where philosophy, theology, and law were taught, the forerunner of today's [University of Zagreb](/wiki/University_of_Zagreb "University of Zagreb").{#cite_ref-56}

During the 17th and 18th centuries, Zagreb was badly devastated by fire and by [the plague](/wiki/Bubonic_plague "Bubonic plague"). In 1776, the royal council (government) moved from [Varaždin](/wiki/Vara%C5%BEdin "Varaždin") to Zagreb and during the reign of the Emperor [Joseph II](/wiki/Joseph_II,_Holy_Roman_Emperor "Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor") Zagreb became the headquarters of the [Varaždin](/wiki/Vara%C5%BEdin "Varaždin") and [Karlovac](/wiki/Karlovac "Karlovac") general command.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-HRT-57)^{#cite_ref-HRT_57-0}  

### 19th to mid-20th century {#19th_to_mid-20th_century}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: 19th to mid-20th century")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Bakrorez_panorame_Zagreba_iz_1822.jpg/200px-Bakrorez_panorame_Zagreba_iz_1822.jpg)](/wiki/File:Bakrorez_panorame_Zagreba_iz_1822.jpg) Copperplate of the panorama of Zagreb from 1822  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Demonstracije_u_Zagrebu_1918.jpg/200px-Demonstracije_u_Zagrebu_1918.jpg)](/wiki/File:Demonstracije_u_Zagrebu_1918.jpg)  
Mass protests in Zagreb against the unification of the [State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs](/wiki/State_of_Slovenes,_Croats_and_Serbs "State of Slovenes, Croats and Serbs") with the Kingdom of Serbia in 1918.  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Ulazak_partizana_u_Zagreb%2C_9._svibnja_1945._godine.jpg/200px-Ulazak_partizana_u_Zagreb%2C_9._svibnja_1945._godine.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ulazak_partizana_u_Zagreb,_9._svibnja_1945._godine.jpg)  
[Croatian Partisans](/wiki/Croatian_Partisans "Croatian Partisans") enter [Ban Jelačić Square](/wiki/Ban_Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87_Square "Ban Jelačić Square") on May 9, 1945, national celebration on the square

In the 19th century, Zagreb was the center of the [Croatian National Revival](/wiki/Illyrian_movement "Illyrian movement") and saw the foundation of important cultural and historic institutions. In 1850, the town was united under its first [mayor](/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Zagreb "List of mayors of Zagreb") -- [Janko Kamauf](/wiki/Janko_Kamauf "Janko Kamauf").^[\[56\]](#cite_note-HRT-57)^{#cite_ref-HRT_57-1}

The first railway line to connect Zagreb with [Zidani Most](/wiki/Zidani_Most "Zidani Most") and [Sisak](/wiki/Sisak "Sisak") opened in 1862 and in 1863 Zagreb received a [gasworks](/wiki/Gasworks "Gasworks"). Since 1 January 1877, the [Grič cannon](/wiki/Gri%C4%8D_cannon "Grič cannon") fires daily from the [Lotrščak Tower](/wiki/Lotr%C5%A1%C4%8Dak_Tower "Lotrščak Tower") on [Grič](/wiki/Gri%C4%8D,_Zagreb "Grič, Zagreb") to mark midday. The Zagreb [waterworks](/wiki/Water_supply "Water supply") opened in 1878.

After the [1880 Zagreb earthquake](/wiki/1880_Zagreb_earthquake "1880 Zagreb earthquake"),^[\[57\]](#cite_note-58)^ up to the 1914 outbreak of [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I"), development flourished and the town received the characteristic layout which it has today. The first horse-drawn [tram](/wiki/Tram "Tram") dated from 1891. The construction of railway lines enabled the old suburbs to merge gradually into [Donji Grad](/wiki/Donji_grad_(Zagreb) "Donji grad (Zagreb)"), characterized by a regular block pattern that prevails in [Central European](/wiki/Central_Europe "Central Europe") cities. This bustling core includes many imposing buildings, monuments, and parks as well as a multitude of museums, theatres, and cinemas. An [electric-power plant](/wiki/Power_station "Power station") was built in 1907.{#cite_ref-58}

The first half of the 20th century saw a considerable expansion of Zagreb. Before World War I, the city expanded and neighborhoods like [Stara Peščenica](/wiki/Stara_Pe%C5%A1%C4%8Denica "Stara Peščenica") in the east and [Črnomerec](/wiki/%C4%8Crnomerec "Črnomerec") in the west grew up. The Rokov perivoj neighbourhood, noted for its [Art Nouveau](/wiki/Art_Nouveau "Art Nouveau") features, was established at the start of the century.^[\[58\]](#cite_note-59)^{#cite_ref-59}

After the war, [working-class](/wiki/Working_class "Working class") districts such as [Trnje](/wiki/Trnje,_Zagreb "Trnje, Zagreb") emerged between the railway and the [Sava](/wiki/Sava "Sava"), whereas the construction of residential districts on the hills of the southern slopes of [Medvednica](/wiki/Medvednica "Medvednica") was completed [between the two World Wars](/wiki/Interwar_period "Interwar period").

In the 1920s, the population of Zagreb increased by 70 percent -- the largest demographic boom in the history of the town. In 1926, the first [radio station](/wiki/Radio_broadcasting "Radio broadcasting") in the region began broadcasting from Zagreb, and in 1947 the [Zagreb Fair](/wiki/Zagreb_Fair "Zagreb Fair") opened.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-HRT-57)^{#cite_ref-HRT_57-2}

During World War II, Zagreb became the capital of the [Independent State of Croatia](/wiki/Independent_State_of_Croatia "Independent State of Croatia") (1941--1945), which was backed by [Nazi Germany](/wiki/Nazi_Germany "Nazi Germany") and by the [Italians](/wiki/Fascism_in_Italy "Fascism in Italy"). The history of [Zagreb in World War II](/wiki/Zagreb_in_World_War_II "Zagreb in World War II") became rife with incidents of régime terror and resistance sabotage - the [Ustaša](/wiki/Usta%C5%A1a "Ustaša") régime had thousands of people executed during the war in and near the city. [Partisans](/wiki/Partisans_(Yugoslavia) "Partisans (Yugoslavia)") took the city at the end of the war. From 1945 until 1990, Zagreb functioned as the capital of the [Socialist Republic of Croatia](/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Croatia "Socialist Republic of Croatia"), one of the six constituent socialist republics of the [Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia](/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia "Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia").  

### Contemporary era {#Contemporary_era}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Contemporary era")\]

The area between the railway and the Sava river witnessed a new construction-boom after World War II. After the mid-1950s, construction of new residential areas south of the Sava river began, resulting in [Novi Zagreb](/wiki/Novi_Zagreb "Novi Zagreb") (Croatian for *New Zagreb* ), originally called "Južni Zagreb" (*Southern Zagreb* ).^[\[59\]](#cite_note-juzni_zagreb-60)^ From 1999 Novi Zagreb has comprised two [city districts](/wiki/City_districts "City districts"): [Novi Zagreb -- zapad](/wiki/Novi_Zagreb_%E2%80%93_zapad "Novi Zagreb – zapad") (*New Zagreb -- West* ) and [Novi Zagreb -- istok](/wiki/Novi_Zagreb_%E2%80%93_istok "Novi Zagreb – istok") (*New Zagreb -- East*){#cite_ref-juzni_zagreb_60-0}

The city also expanded westward and eastward, incorporating [Dubrava](/wiki/Dubrava,_Zagreb "Dubrava, Zagreb"), Podsused, [Jarun](/wiki/Jarun "Jarun"), [Blato](/wiki/Blato,_Zagreb "Blato, Zagreb"), and other settlements.

The cargo railway hub and the [international airport](/wiki/International_airport "International airport") ([Pleso](/wiki/Zagreb_Airport "Zagreb Airport")) were built south of the Sava river. The largest [industrial zone](/wiki/Industrial_district "Industrial district") (Žitnjak) in the south-eastern part of the city, represents an extension of the industrial zones on the eastern outskirts of the city, between the Sava and the Prigorje region. Zagreb hosted the [Summer Universiade](/wiki/1987_Summer_Universiade "1987 Summer Universiade") in 1987.^[\[56\]](#cite_note-HRT-57)^ This event initiated the creation of pedestrian-only zones in the city centre and extensive new sport infrastructure, lacking until then, all around the city.^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-HRT_57-3}

During the 1991--1995 [Croatian War of Independence](/wiki/Croatian_War_of_Independence "Croatian War of Independence"), the city saw some [sporadic fighting](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Barracks "Battle of the Barracks") around its [JNA](/wiki/Yugoslav_People%27s_Army "Yugoslav People's Army") [army barracks](/wiki/Barracks "Barracks"), but escaped major damage. In May 1995, it was targeted by Serb [rocket artillery](/wiki/Rocket_artillery "Rocket artillery") in two [rocket attacks](/wiki/Zagreb_rocket_attacks "Zagreb rocket attacks") which killed seven civilians and wounded many.

An urbanized area connects Zagreb with the surrounding towns of [Zaprešić](/wiki/Zapre%C5%A1i%C4%87 "Zaprešić"), [Samobor](/wiki/Samobor "Samobor"), [Dugo Selo](/wiki/Dugo_Selo "Dugo Selo"), and [Velika Gorica](/wiki/Velika_Gorica "Velika Gorica"). Sesvete was the first and the closest area to become a part of the [agglomeration](/wiki/Urban_agglomeration "Urban agglomeration") and is already included in the City of Zagreb for administrative purposes and now forms the easternmost city district.^[\[60\]](#cite_note-61)^{#cite_ref-61}  

Geography {#Geography}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Geography")\]  

### Climate {#Climate}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Climate")\]

The climate of Zagreb is classified as an [oceanic climate](/wiki/Oceanic_climate "Oceanic climate") ([Köppen](/wiki/Humid_temperate_climate "Humid temperate climate"): *Cfb* ), bordering a [humid continental climate](/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") (*Dfb*).
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e9/Zagreb%2C_Croatia_ESA24383472.jpeg/200px-Zagreb%2C_Croatia_ESA24383472.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Zagreb,_Croatia_ESA24383472.jpeg) Satellite view of Zagreb [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Zagreb_areal_view_%2813%29.jpg/200px-Zagreb_areal_view_%2813%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zagreb_areal_view_(13).jpg) Aerial view of Zagreb's downtown

Zagreb has four distinct seasons. Summers are generally warm, sometimes hot. In late May it gets significantly warmer, temperatures start rising and it often becomes very warm or even hot with occasional afternoon and evening thunderstorms. Heatwaves can occur but are short-lived. Temperatures rise above 30 °C (86 °F) on average 14.6 days each summer. During summertime, rainfall is abundant and it mainly falls during thunderstorms. With 840 mm of precipitation per year, Zagreb is Europe's ninth wettest capital, receiving less precipitation than [Luxembourg](/wiki/Luxembourg_City "Luxembourg City") but more than [Brussels](/wiki/Brussels "Brussels"), [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris") or [London](/wiki/London "London"). Compared to these cities, however, Zagreb has fewer rainy days, but the annual rainfall is higher due to heavier showers occurring mainly in late spring and summer. Autumn in its early stage often brings pleasant and sunny weather with occasional episodes of rain later in the season. Late autumn is characterized by a mild increase in the number of rainy days and a gradual decrease in daily temperature averages. Morning fog is common from mid-October to January, with northern city districts at the foothills of the [Medvednica](/wiki/Medvednica "Medvednica") mountain as well as south-central districts along the [Sava](/wiki/Sava "Sava") river being more prone to longer fog accumulation. Winters are relatively cold, bringing overcast skies and a precipitation decrease pattern. February is the driest month, averaging 39 mm of precipitation. On average there are 29 days with snowfall, with the first snow usually falling in early December. However, in recent years, the number of days with snowfall in wintertime has decreased considerably. Spring is characterized by often pleasant but changeable weather. As the season progresses, sunny days become more frequent, bringing higher temperatures. Sometimes cold spells can occur as well, mostly in the season's early stages. The average daily mean temperature in the winter is around 1 °C (34 °F) (from December to February) and the average temperature in the summer is 20 °C (68.0 °F).^[\[61\]](#cite_note-normals-62)^ The highest recorded temperature at the Maksimir weather station was 40.4 °C (104.7 °F) in July 1950, and lowest was −27.3 °C (−17.1 °F) in February 1956.^[\[62\]](#cite_note-HRMETEO-63)^ A temperature of −30.5 °C (−22.9 °F) was recorded on the since defunct Borongaj Airfield in February 1940.^[\[63\]](#cite_note-64)^{#cite_ref-64}

### Cityscape {#Cityscape}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Cityscape")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Zagreb_hl001-pan.jpg/800px-Zagreb_hl001-pan.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zagreb_hl001-pan.jpg "Panoramic view from Zagreb's Upper town.")  
[](/wiki/File:Zagreb_hl001-pan.jpg "File:Zagreb hl001-pan.jpg")
Panoramic view from Zagreb's [Upper town](/wiki/Gornji_Grad%E2%80%93Medve%C5%A1%C4%8Dak "Gornji Grad–Medveščak").

The most important historical [high-rise](/wiki/High-rise "High-rise") constructions are [Neboder](/wiki/Neboder "Neboder") (1958) on [Ban Jelačić Square](/wiki/Ban_Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87_Square "Ban Jelačić Square"), [Cibona Tower](/wiki/Cibona_Tower "Cibona Tower") (1987), and [Zagrepčanka](/wiki/Zagrep%C4%8Danka "Zagrepčanka") (1976) on Savska Street, [Mamutica](/wiki/Mamutica "Mamutica") in Travno ([Novi Zagreb -- istok](/wiki/Novi_Zagreb_%E2%80%93_istok "Novi Zagreb – istok") district, built in 1974) and [Zagreb TV Tower](/wiki/Zagreb_TV_Tower "Zagreb TV Tower") on [Sljeme](/wiki/Medvednica "Medvednica") (built in 1973).^[\[65\]](#cite_note-66)^{#cite_ref-66}

In the 2000s, the City Assembly approved a new plan that allowed for the many recent high-rise buildings in Zagreb, such as the Almeria Tower, [Eurotower](/wiki/Eurotower_(Zagreb) "Eurotower (Zagreb)"), [HOTO Tower](/wiki/HOTO_Tower "HOTO Tower"), [Zagrebtower](/wiki/Zagrebtower "Zagrebtower"), [Sky Office Tower](/wiki/Sky_Office_Tower "Sky Office Tower") and the [tallest high-rise building](/wiki/Tallest_buildings_in_Croatia "Tallest buildings in Croatia") in Zagreb [Strojarska Business Center](/wiki/Strojarska_Business_Center "Strojarska Business Center").^[\[66\]](#cite_note-skyoffice-67)^^[\[67\]](#cite_note-empoirs-68)^{#cite_ref-empoirs_68-0}

In [Novi Zagreb](/wiki/Novi_Zagreb "Novi Zagreb"), the neighbourhoods of [Blato](/wiki/Blato,_Zagreb "Blato, Zagreb") and [Lanište](/wiki/Lani%C5%A1te,_Croatia "Lanište, Croatia") expanded significantly, including the [Zagreb Arena](/wiki/Arena_Zagreb "Arena Zagreb") and the adjoining business centre.^[\[68\]](#cite_note-blato_lanište-69)^{#cite_ref-blato_lanište_69-0}

Due to a long-standing restriction that forbade the construction of 10-story or higher buildings, most of Zagreb's high-rise buildings date from the 1970s and 1980s and new apartment buildings on the outskirts of the city are usually 4--8 floors tall. Exceptions to the restriction have been made in recent years, such as permitting the construction of high-rise buildings in Lanište or Kajzerica.^[\[69\]](#cite_note-javno-70)^{#cite_ref-javno_70-0}  

### Surroundings {#Surroundings}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Surroundings")\]  
Further information: [Zagreb County](/wiki/Zagreb_County "Zagreb County"), [Prigorje](/wiki/Prigorje "Prigorje"), [Hrvatsko Zagorje](/wiki/Hrvatsko_Zagorje "Hrvatsko Zagorje"), and [Turopolje](/wiki/Turopolje "Turopolje")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Stari_grad_Medvedgrad_-_Zagreb_02.jpg/220px-Stari_grad_Medvedgrad_-_Zagreb_02.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stari_grad_Medvedgrad_-_Zagreb_02.jpg) [Medvedgrad](/wiki/Medvedgrad "Medvedgrad") fortress

The wider Zagreb area has been continuously inhabited since the prehistoric period, as witnessed by archaeological findings in the [Veternica cave](/wiki/Veternica_cave "Veternica cave") from the [Paleolithic](/wiki/Paleolithic "Paleolithic") and excavation of the remains of the Roman Andautonia near the present village of Šćitarjevo.

Picturesque former villages on the slopes of Medvednica, Šestine, Gračani, and Remete, maintain their rich traditions, including folk costumes, Šestine umbrellas, and [gingerbread](/wiki/Gingerbread "Gingerbread") products.

To the north is the [Medvednica](/wiki/Medvednica "Medvednica") Mountain ([Croatian](/wiki/Croatian_language "Croatian language"): *Zagrebačka gora* ), with its highest peak [Sljeme](/wiki/Medvednica "Medvednica") (1,035 m), where one of the tallest structures in Croatia, [Zagreb TV Tower](/wiki/Zagreb_TV_Tower "Zagreb TV Tower") is located. The Sava and the [Kupa](/wiki/Kupa_(river) "Kupa (river)") valleys are to the south of Zagreb, and the region of [Hrvatsko Zagorje](/wiki/Hrvatsko_Zagorje "Hrvatsko Zagorje") is located on the other (northern) side of the Medvednica hill. In mid-January 2005, Sljeme held its first [World Ski Championship tournament](/wiki/FIS_Alpine_World_Ski_Championships "FIS Alpine World Ski Championships").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Sljeme_%2831374028193%29.jpg/170px-Sljeme_%2831374028193%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sljeme_(31374028193).jpg) [Zagreb TV Tower](/wiki/Zagreb_TV_Tower "Zagreb TV Tower")

From the summit, weather permitting, the vista reaches as far as [Velebit](/wiki/Velebit "Velebit") Range along Croatia's rocky northern coast, as well as the snow-capped peaks of the towering [Julian Alps](/wiki/Julian_Alps "Julian Alps") in neighboring [Slovenia](/wiki/Slovenia "Slovenia"). There are several lodging villages, offering accommodation and restaurants for hikers. Skiers visit Sljeme, which has four ski-runs, three ski-lifts, and a chairlift.

The old [Medvedgrad](/wiki/Medvedgrad "Medvedgrad"), a recently restored medieval [burg](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Special:Search/burg "wikt:Special:Search/burg") was built in the 13th century on Medvednica hill. It overlooks the western part of the city and also hosts the *Shrine of the Homeland* , a memorial with an [eternal flame](/wiki/Eternal_flame "Eternal flame"), where Croatia pays reverence to all its heroes fallen for [homeland](/wiki/Homeland "Homeland") in its history, customarily on [national holidays](/wiki/Public_holiday "Public holiday"). The ruined medieval fortress [Susedgrad](/wiki/Susedgrad "Susedgrad") is located on the far-western side of Medvednica hill. It has been abandoned since the early 17th century, but it is visited during the year.

Zagreb occasionally experiences earthquakes, due to the proximity of [Žumberak](/wiki/%C5%BDumberak "Žumberak")-[Medvednica](/wiki/Medvednica "Medvednica") fault zone.^[\[70\]](#cite_note-71)^ It's classified as an area of high seismic activity.^[\[71\]](#cite_note-embassy_earthquake-72)^ The area around Medvednica was the epicentre of the [1880 Zagreb earthquake](/wiki/1880_Zagreb_earthquake "1880 Zagreb earthquake") (magnitude 6.3), and the area is known for occasional landslide threatening houses in the area.^[\[72\]](#cite_note-landslide_survey_croatian-73)^ The proximity of strong seismic sources presents a real danger of strong earthquakes.^[\[72\]](#cite_note-landslide_survey_croatian-73)^ Croatian Chief of [Office of Emergency Management](/wiki/Office_of_Emergency_Management "Office of Emergency Management") Pavle Kalinić stated Zagreb experiences around 400 earthquakes a year, most of them being imperceptible. However, in case of a strong earthquake, it's expected that 3,000 people would die and up to 15,000 would be wounded.^[\[73\]](#cite_note-74)^ In 2020 the city experienced a [5.5 magnitude earthquake](/wiki/2020_Zagreb_earthquake "2020 Zagreb earthquake"), which damaged various buildings in the historic downtown area. The city's iconic cathedral lost the cross off of one of its towers. This earthquake was the strongest one to affect the city since the destructive [1880 Zagreb earthquake](/wiki/1880_Zagreb_earthquake "1880 Zagreb earthquake").{#cite_ref-74}  

Demographics {#Demographics}
----------------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Demographics")\]  
Main article: [Demographics of Zagreb](/wiki/Demographics_of_Zagreb "Demographics of Zagreb")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Zagreb_population_pyramid.svg/220px-Zagreb_population_pyramid.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Zagreb_population_pyramid.svg) Zagreb population pyramid in 2021

Zagreb is by far [the largest city in Croatia](/wiki/Demographics_of_Croatia "Demographics of Croatia") in terms of population, which was 767,131 in 2021.^[\[3\]](#cite_note-Census_2021-3)^{#cite_ref-Census_2021_3-2}

[Historical population]

Zagreb [metropolitan area](/wiki/Metropolitan_area "Metropolitan area") population is slightly above 1.0 million inhabitants,^[\[74\]](#cite_note-CityMayors-75)^ as it includes the [Zagreb County](/wiki/Zagreb_County "Zagreb County").^[\[75\]](#cite_note-zg_cc-76)^ Zagreb metropolitan area makes approximately a quarter of a total [population of Croatia](/wiki/Demographics_of_Croatia "Demographics of Croatia"). In 1997, the City of Zagreb itself was given special County status, separating it from Zagreb County,^[\[76\]](#cite_note-77)^ although it remains the [administrative centre](/wiki/Administrative_centre "Administrative centre") of both.{#cite_ref-77}

The majority of its citizens are [Croats](/wiki/Croats "Croats") making up 93.53% of the city's population (2021 census). The same census records around 49,605 residents belonging to [ethnic minorities](/wiki/Ethnic_minorities_in_Croatia "Ethnic minorities in Croatia"): 12,035 [Serbs](/wiki/Serbs_of_Croatia "Serbs of Croatia") (1.57%), 6,566 [Bosniaks](/wiki/Bosniaks_of_Croatia "Bosniaks of Croatia") (0.86%), 3,475 [Albanians](/wiki/Albanians_of_Croatia "Albanians of Croatia") (0.45%), 2,167 [Romani](/wiki/Romani_people_in_Croatia "Romani people in Croatia") (0.28%), 1,312 [Slovenes](/wiki/Slovenes_of_Croatia "Slovenes of Croatia") (0.17%), 1,036 [Macedonians](/wiki/Macedonians_of_Croatia "Macedonians of Croatia") (0.15%), 865 [Montenegrins](/wiki/Montenegrins_of_Croatia "Montenegrins of Croatia") (0.11%), and a number of other smaller communities.^[\[77\]](#cite_note-78)^{#cite_ref-78}

After the easing of COVID-19 pandemic restrictions, thousands of foreign workers immigrated to Zagreb due to the shortage of labor force in Croatia. These workers primarily come from countries such as [Nepal](/wiki/Nepal "Nepal"), [the Philippines](/wiki/Philippines "Philippines"), [India](/wiki/India "India"), and [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh"), as well as some European countries including [Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Bosnia and Herzegovina"), [Serbia](/wiki/Serbia "Serbia"), [Kosovo](/wiki/Kosovo "Kosovo") and [North Macedonia](/wiki/North_Macedonia "North Macedonia").^[\[78\]](#cite_note-79)^{#cite_ref-79}

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Sabor-pro%C4%8Delje.jpg/200px-Sabor-pro%C4%8Delje.jpg)](/wiki/File:Sabor-pro%C4%8Delje.jpg) [Croatian Parliament (Sabor)](/wiki/Croatian_Parliament "Croatian Parliament") on Saint Mark's Square. [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Banski_dvori_%28kolovoz_2021%29.jpg/200px-Banski_dvori_%28kolovoz_2021%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Banski_dvori_(kolovoz_2021).jpg) [Banski Dvori](/wiki/Banski_Dvori "Banski Dvori") seat of the [Government of Croatia](/wiki/Government_of_Croatia "Government of Croatia") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/George_W._Bush_in_Zagreb.jpg/200px-George_W._Bush_in_Zagreb.jpg)](/wiki/File:George_W._Bush_in_Zagreb.jpg) [George W. Bush](/wiki/George_W._Bush "George W. Bush") giving a speech on [St. Mark's Square](/wiki/St._Mark%27s_Square,_Zagreb "St. Mark's Square, Zagreb") in front of [Banski Dvori](/wiki/Banski_Dvori "Banski Dvori"), the seat of the [Croatian government](/wiki/Government_of_Croatia "Government of Croatia"), 4 April 2008

Zagreb is the capital of the [Republic of Croatia](/wiki/Croatia "Croatia"), its political center and the center of various state institutions.

On the [St. Mark's Square](/wiki/St._Mark%27s_Square,_Zagreb "St. Mark's Square, Zagreb") are the seats of the [Government of the Republic of Croatia](/wiki/Government_of_Croatia "Government of Croatia") in the [Banski Dvori](/wiki/Banski_Dvori "Banski Dvori") complex, the [Croatian Parliament](/wiki/Croatian_Parliament "Croatian Parliament") (Sabor), as well as the [Constitutional Court of the Republic of Croatia](/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Croatia "Constitutional Court of Croatia"). Various ministries and state agencies are located in the wider area of the City of Zagreb.  

### City governance {#City_governance}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=16 "Edit section: City governance")\]  
See also: [List of mayors of Zagreb](/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Zagreb "List of mayors of Zagreb") and [Zagreb Assembly](/wiki/Zagreb_Assembly "Zagreb Assembly")

The current mayor of Zagreb is [Tomislav Tomašević](/wiki/Tomislav_Toma%C5%A1evi%C4%87 "Tomislav Tomašević") ('[We can!](/wiki/We_can!_(Croatia) "We can! (Croatia)")'), elected in the [2021 Zagreb local elections](/wiki/2021_Zagreb_local_elections "2021 Zagreb local elections"), the second round of which was held on 30 May 2021. There are two deputy mayors elected from the same list, Danijela Dolenec and Luka Korlaet.^[\[85\]](#cite_note-88)^{#cite_ref-88}

The [Zagreb Assembly](/wiki/Zagreb_Assembly "Zagreb Assembly") is composed of 51 representatives, elected in the 2021 Zagreb local elections.

The [Zagreb Assembly](/wiki/Zagreb_Assembly "Zagreb Assembly") is composed of 51 representatives, elected in the 2021 Zagreb local elections.

According to the [Constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_Croatia "Constitution of Croatia"), the city of Zagreb, as the capital of Croatia, has a special status. As such, Zagreb performs [self-governing](/wiki/Self-governance "Self-governance") public affairs of both [city](/wiki/List_of_cities_and_towns_in_Croatia "List of cities and towns in Croatia") and [county](/wiki/Counties_of_Croatia "Counties of Croatia"). It is also the seat of the [Zagreb County](/wiki/Zagreb_County "Zagreb County") which encircles Zagreb.

The city administration bodies are the **[Zagreb City Assembly](/wiki/Zagreb_Assembly "Zagreb Assembly")** (*Gradska skupština Grada Zagreba* ) as the representative body and the **[mayor of Zagreb](/wiki/List_of_mayors_of_Zagreb "List of mayors of Zagreb")** (*Gradonačelnik Grada Zagreba*) who is the executive head of the city.

The City Assembly is the representative body of the citizens of the City of Zagreb elected for a four-year term on the basis of [universal suffrage](/wiki/Universal_suffrage "Universal suffrage") in [direct elections](/wiki/Direct_elections "Direct elections") by [secret ballot](/wiki/Secret_ballot "Secret ballot") using [proportional system](/wiki/Proportional_representation "Proportional representation") with [d'Hondt method](/wiki/D%27Hondt_method "D'Hondt method") in a manner specified by law. There are 51 representatives in the City Assembly, among them the president and vice-presidents of the assembly are elected by the representatives.

Before 2009, the mayor was elected by the City Assembly. It was changed to direct elections by [majoritarian vote](/wiki/Majority_vote "Majority vote") ([two-round system](/wiki/Two-round_system "Two-round system")) in 2009. The mayor is the head of the city administration and has two deputies (directly elected together with him/her).

The term of office of the mayor (and his/her deputies) is four years. The mayor (with the deputies) may be recalled by a referendum according to the law (not less than 20% of all electors in the City of Zagreb or not less than two-thirds of the [Zagreb Assembly](/wiki/Zagreb_Assembly "Zagreb Assembly") city deputies have the right to initiate a [city referendum](/wiki/Recall_referendum "Recall referendum") regarding recalling of the mayor; when a majority of voters taking part in the referendum vote in favor of the recall, provided that majority includes not less than one-third of all persons entitled to vote in the City of Zagreb, i.e.
1⁄3 of persons in the City of Zagreb [electoral register](/wiki/Electoral_register "Electoral register"), the mayor's mandate shall be deemed revoked and [special mayoral by-elections](/wiki/Special_elections "Special elections") shall be held).

In the City of Zagreb, the [mayor](/wiki/Mayors_of_Zagreb "Mayors of Zagreb") is also responsible for the state administration (due to the special status of Zagreb as a "city with county rights", there isn't a State Administration Office which in all counties performs tasks of the central government). City administration offices, institutions and services (18 [city offices](/wiki/Municipal_service "Municipal service"), 1 [public institute](/wiki/Municipal_service "Municipal service") or [bureau](/wiki/Municipal_service "Municipal service") and 2 [city services](/wiki/Municipal_services "Municipal services")) have been founded for performing activities within the self-administrative sphere and activities entrusted by the state administration. The city administrative bodies are managed by the principals (appointed by the mayor for a four-year term of office, may be appointed again to the same duty). The City Assembly Professional Service is managed by the secretary of the City Assembly (appointed by the Assembly).

Local government is organised in 17 [city districts](/wiki/Districts_of_Zagreb "Districts of Zagreb") represented by City District Councils. Residents of districts elect members of councils.^[\[89\]](#cite_note-92)^{#cite_ref-92}

### Tourism {#Tourism}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Tourism")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/St._Mark%27s_Church_Zagreb.jpg/200px-St._Mark%27s_Church_Zagreb.jpg)](/wiki/File:St._Mark%27s_Church_Zagreb.jpg) View of the [St. Mark's Church](/wiki/St._Mark%27s_Church,_Zagreb "St. Mark's Church, Zagreb") with the famous colourful roof representing the coat of arms of the [Triune Kingdom](/wiki/Triune_Kingdom "Triune Kingdom") of [Croatia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Croatia_(Habsburg) "Kingdom of Croatia (Habsburg)"), [Dalmatia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Dalmatia "Kingdom of Dalmatia") and [Slavonia](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Slavonia "Kingdom of Slavonia") (left), and the city of Zagreb (right)

Zagreb is an important tourist center, not only in terms of passengers traveling from the rest of Europe to the Adriatic Sea but also as a travel destination itself. Since the end of the [war](/wiki/History_of_Croatia "History of Croatia"), it has attracted close to a million visitors annually, mainly from Austria, Germany, and Italy, and in recent years many tourists from far east (South Korea, Japan, China, and last two years, from India). It has become an important tourist destination, not only in Croatia, but considering the whole region of southeastern Europe. There are many interesting sights and happenings for tourists to attend in Zagreb, for example, the two statues of Saint George, one at the [Republic of Croatia Square](/wiki/Republic_of_Croatia_Square "Republic of Croatia Square"), the other at the [Stone Gate](/wiki/Stone_Gate "Stone Gate"), where the image of the Virgin Mary is said to be the only thing that did not burn in the 17th-century fire. Also, there is an art installation starting in the Bogovićeva Street, called [Nine Views](/wiki/Nine_Views "Nine Views"). Zagreb is also famous for its award-winning [Christmas market](/wiki/Christmas_market "Christmas market") that had been named the one in Europe for three consecutive years (2015, 2016 and 2017) by *European Best Destinations* .^[\[114\]](#cite_note-117)^^[\[115\]](#cite_note-118)^{#cite_ref-118}

The capital is also known for its many restaurants^[\[116\]](#cite_note-119)^^[\[117\]](#cite_note-120)^ that serve not only traditional [Croatian food](/wiki/Croatian_cuisine "Croatian cuisine") and classic dishes. In addition to that, a lot of [international hotel chains](/wiki/List_of_chained-brand_hotels "List of chained-brand hotels") are offering their accommodations in Zagreb, including: [Best Western](/wiki/Best_Western "Best Western"), [Hilton Worldwide](/wiki/Hilton_Worldwide "Hilton Worldwide"): ([DoubleTree by Hilton](/wiki/DoubleTree_by_Hilton "DoubleTree by Hilton"), [Hilton Garden Inn](/wiki/Hilton_Garden_Inn "Hilton Garden Inn") \& [Canopy by Hilton](/wiki/Canopy_by_Hilton "Canopy by Hilton")), [Marriott International](/wiki/Marriott_International "Marriott International"): ([Sheraton Hotels](/wiki/Sheraton_Hotels "Sheraton Hotels") \& [The Westin](/wiki/The_Westin "The Westin")), [Radisson Hotel Group](/wiki/Radisson_Hotel_Group "Radisson Hotel Group"), [Mövenpick Hotels \& Resorts](/wiki/M%C3%B6venpick_Hotels_%26_Resorts "Mövenpick Hotels & Resorts") and a former [Regent Hotels \& Resorts](/wiki/Regent_Hotels_%26_Resorts "Regent Hotels & Resorts") which is now [Esplanade Zagreb Hotel](/wiki/Esplanade_Zagreb_Hotel "Esplanade Zagreb Hotel").{#cite_ref-120}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Ku%C4%87a_Kallina_u_Zagrebu.jpg/220px-Ku%C4%87a_Kallina_u_Zagrebu.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ku%C4%87a_Kallina_u_Zagrebu.jpg) Secession building [Kallina House](/wiki/Kallina_House "Kallina House")

The historical part of the city to the north of [Ban Jelačić Square](/wiki/Ban_Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87_Square "Ban Jelačić Square") is composed of the [Gornji Grad](/wiki/Gradec,_Zagreb "Gradec, Zagreb") and [Kaptol](/wiki/Kaptol,_Zagreb "Kaptol, Zagreb"), a medieval urban complex of churches, palaces, museums, galleries and government buildings that are popular with tourists on sightseeing tours. The historic district can be reached on foot, starting from the Ban Jelačić Square, the center of Zagreb, or by a [funicular](/wiki/Funicular "Funicular") on nearby Tomićeva Street. Each Saturday, (from April until the end of September), on [St. Mark's Square](/wiki/St._Mark%27s_Square,_Zagreb "St. Mark's Square, Zagreb") in the [Upper town](/wiki/Gradec,_Zagreb "Gradec, Zagreb"), tourists can meet members of the Order of The Silver Dragon (*Red Srebrnog Zmaja* ), who reenact famous historical conflicts between [Gradec](/wiki/Gradec,_Zagreb_County "Gradec, Zagreb County") and [Kaptol](/wiki/Kaptol,_Zagreb "Kaptol, Zagreb").

In 2010 more than 600,000^[\[118\]](#cite_note-121)^ tourists visited the city, with a 10%^[\[119\]](#cite_note-122)^ increase seen in 2011. In 2012 a total of 675 707 tourists^[\[120\]](#cite_note-123)^ visited the city. A record number of tourists visited Zagreb in 2017, 1.286.087, up 16% compared to the year before, which generated 2.263.758 overnight stays, up 14,8%.{#cite_ref-123}  

#### Souvenirs and gastronomy {#Souvenirs_and_gastronomy}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=23 "Edit section: Souvenirs and gastronomy")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Licitars2.jpg/200px-Licitars2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Licitars2.jpg) [Licitar](/wiki/Licitar "Licitar") hearts, a popular souvenir  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Mlinci.jpg/150px-Mlinci.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mlinci.jpg)  
[Turkey](/wiki/Turkey_(meat) "Turkey (meat)") served with [mlinci](/wiki/Mlinci "Mlinci")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8b/Samobor_kremsnita.jpg/150px-Samobor_kremsnita.jpg)](/wiki/File:Samobor_kremsnita.jpg)  
[Kremšnita](/wiki/Cremeschnitte "Cremeschnitte")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/af/%C5%A0trukli_iz_Okrugljaka.jpg/150px-%C5%A0trukli_iz_Okrugljaka.jpg)](/wiki/File:%C5%A0trukli_iz_Okrugljaka.jpg)  
[Štrukli](/wiki/%C5%A0trukli "Štrukli")

Numerous shops, boutiques, store houses and [shopping centers](/wiki/Shopping_mall "Shopping mall") offer a variety of quality clothing. There are about fourteen big shopping centers in Zagreb. Zagreb's offerings include [crystal](/wiki/Crystal "Crystal"), [china](/wiki/Chinese_ceramics "Chinese ceramics") and [ceramics](/wiki/Pottery "Pottery"), [wicker](/wiki/Wicker "Wicker") or [straw](/wiki/Straw "Straw") baskets, and top-quality Croatian wines and [gastronomic](/wiki/Gastronomy "Gastronomy") products.

Notable Zagreb souvenirs are the [tie](/wiki/Necktie "Necktie") or *cravat* , an accessory named after Croats who wore characteristic scarves around their necks in the [Thirty Years' War](/wiki/Thirty_Years%27_War "Thirty Years' War") in the 17th century and the [ball-point pen](/wiki/Ballpoint_pen "Ballpoint pen"), a tool developed from the inventions by [Slavoljub Eduard Penkala](/wiki/Slavoljub_Eduard_Penkala "Slavoljub Eduard Penkala"), an inventor and a citizen of Zagreb.

Many Zagreb restaurants offer various specialties of [national](/wiki/Croatian_cuisine "Croatian cuisine") and [international cuisine](/wiki/Fusion_cuisine "Fusion cuisine"). Domestic products which deserve to be tasted include [turkey](/wiki/Turkey_as_food "Turkey as food"), [duck](/wiki/Duck_(meat) "Duck (meat)") or goose with *[mlinci](/wiki/Mlinci "Mlinci")* (flat pasta, soaked in roast juices), a famous *Zagrebački odrezak* (type of [cordon bleu](/wiki/Cordon_bleu_(dish) "Cordon bleu (dish)")), *[Štrukli](/wiki/Zagorski_%C5%A1trukli "Zagorski štrukli")* ([cottage cheese](/wiki/Cottage_cheese "Cottage cheese") [strudel](/wiki/Strudel "Strudel")), *sir i vrhnje* ([cottage cheese](/wiki/Cottage_cheese "Cottage cheese") with cream), *[kremšnite](/wiki/Cremeschnitte "Cremeschnitte")* ([custard](/wiki/Custard "Custard") slices in flaky pastry), *orehnjača* (traditional [walnut](/wiki/Walnut#Nuts "Walnut") roll), and *[sarma](/wiki/Sarma_(food) "Sarma (food)")* ([Sauerkraut](/wiki/Sauerkraut "Sauerkraut") rolls filed with minced pork meat and rice, served with [mashed potato](/wiki/Mashed_potato "Mashed potato")).
