[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e3/Stra%C3%9Fe_Ilica_in_Zagreb.jpg/200px-Stra%C3%9Fe_Ilica_in_Zagreb.jpg)](/wiki/File:Stra%C3%9Fe_Ilica_in_Zagreb.jpg)  
[Ilica](/wiki/Ilica_(street) "Ilica (street)"), the famous shopping street of the city  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Zagreb_-_Medvedgrad_%2843718446370%29.jpg/200px-Zagreb_-_Medvedgrad_%2843718446370%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zagreb_-_Medvedgrad_(43718446370).jpg)  
[Tkalčićeva Street](/wiki/Tkal%C4%8Di%C4%87eva_Street "Tkalčićeva Street"), commonly known as "Tkalča"(Tkalcha) with many cafes, bars and restaurants of local and foreign cuisine

Zagreb's museums reflect the history, art, and culture not only of Zagreb and Croatia, but also of Europe and the world. Around thirty collections in museums and galleries comprise more than 3.6 million various exhibits, excluding church and private collections.

The [Archaeological Museum](/wiki/Archaeological_Museum,_Zagreb "Archaeological Museum, Zagreb") collections, today consisting of nearly 450,000 varied [archaeological](/wiki/Archaeology "Archaeology") artefacts and monuments, have been gathered over the years from many different sources. These holdings include evidence of Croatian presence in the area.^[\[121\]](#cite_note-zageb_archeo-124)^ The most famous are the Egyptian collection, the [Zagreb mummy](/wiki/Liber_Linteus "Liber Linteus") and bandages with the oldest [Etruscan](/wiki/Old_Italic_alphabet "Old Italic alphabet") inscription in the world (*[Liber Linteus](/wiki/Liber_Linteus "Liber Linteus") Zagrabiensis* ), as well as the [numismatic](/wiki/Coin_collecting "Coin collecting") collection.{#cite_ref-zageb_archeo_124-0}

The [Modern Gallery](/wiki/Modern_Gallery,_Zagreb "Modern Gallery, Zagreb") ([Croatian](/wiki/Croatian_language "Croatian language"): *Moderna galerija* ) holds the most important and comprehensive collection of paintings, sculptures and drawings by 19th- and 20th-century Croatian artists. The collection numbers more than 10,000 works of art, housed since 1934 in the historic Vranyczany Palace in the center of Zagreb, overlooking the Zrinjevac Park. A secondary gallery is the Josip Račić Studio.^[\[122\]](#cite_note-moderngallery-125)^{#cite_ref-moderngallery_125-0}

The [Croatian Natural History Museum](/wiki/Croatian_Natural_History_Museum "Croatian Natural History Museum") holds one of the world's most important collections of [Neanderthal](/wiki/Neanderthal "Neanderthal") remains found at one site.^[\[123\]](#cite_note-zageb_nat-126)^ These are the remains, stone weapons, and tools of prehistoric *[Krapina](/wiki/Krapina "Krapina") man*. The holdings of the Croatian Natural History Museum comprise more than 250,000 specimens distributed among various collections.{#cite_ref-zageb_nat_126-0}

The [Technical Museum](/wiki/Technical_Museum,_Zagreb "Technical Museum, Zagreb") was founded in 1954 and it maintains the oldest preserved machine in the area, dating from 1830, which is still operational. The museum exhibits numerous historic aircraft, cars, machinery and equipment. There are some distinct sections in the museum: the Planetarium, the Apisarium, the Mine (model of mines for coal, iron and [non-ferrous metals](/wiki/Ferrous "Ferrous"), about 300 m (980 ft) long), and the [Nikola Tesla](/wiki/Nikola_Tesla "Nikola Tesla") study.^[\[124\]](#cite_note-zageb_tech-127)^^[\[125\]](#cite_note-128)^{#cite_ref-128}

The [Museum of the City of Zagreb](/wiki/Zagreb_City_Museum "Zagreb City Museum") was established in 1907 by the Association of the Braća Hrvatskog Zmaja. It is located in a restored monumental complex (Popov toranj, the Observatory, Zakmardi Granary) of the former Convent of the [Poor Clares](/wiki/Poor_Clares "Poor Clares"), of 1650.^[\[126\]](#cite_note-zageb_citymus-129)^ The Museum deals with topics from the cultural, artistic, economic and [political history](/wiki/Political_history "Political history") of the city spanning from Roman finds to the [modern period](/wiki/Modern_history "Modern history"). The holdings comprise over 80,000 items arranged systematically into collections of artistic and mundane objects characteristic of the city and its history.{#cite_ref-zageb_citymus_129-0}

The [Arts and Crafts Museum](/wiki/Museum_of_Arts_and_Crafts,_Zagreb "Museum of Arts and Crafts, Zagreb") was founded in 1880 with the intention of preserving the works of art and craft against the new predominance of industrial products. With its 160,000 exhibits, the Arts and Crafts Museum is a national-level museum for artistic production and the history of [material culture](/wiki/Archaeological_culture "Archaeological culture") in Croatia.^[\[127\]](#cite_note-zageb_artsandcrafts-130)^{#cite_ref-zageb_artsandcrafts_130-0}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Umjetni%C4%8Dki_paviljon_u_Zagrebu_04.2021.jpg/220px-Umjetni%C4%8Dki_paviljon_u_Zagrebu_04.2021.jpg)](/wiki/File:Umjetni%C4%8Dki_paviljon_u_Zagrebu_04.2021.jpg)  
[Art Pavilion in Zagreb](/wiki/Art_Pavilion_in_Zagreb "Art Pavilion in Zagreb")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/Mimara_Museum%2C_Zagreb_02.jpg/220px-Mimara_Museum%2C_Zagreb_02.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mimara_Museum,_Zagreb_02.jpg)  
[Mimara Museum](/wiki/Mimara_Museum "Mimara Museum")

The [Ethnographic Museum](/wiki/Ethnographic_Museum,_Zagreb "Ethnographic Museum, Zagreb") was founded in 1919. It lies in the fine Secession building of the one-time Trades Hall of 1903. The ample holdings of about 80,000 items cover the ethnographic heritage of Croatia, classified in three cultural zones: the Pannonian, Dinaric and Adriatic.^[\[128\]](#cite_note-zageb_ethnographic-131)^{#cite_ref-zageb_ethnographic_131-0}

The [Mimara Museum](/wiki/Mimara_Museum "Mimara Museum") an [art museum](/wiki/Art_museum "Art museum"), that was founded with a donation from [Ante Topić Mimara](/wiki/Ante_Topi%C4%87_Mimara "Ante Topić Mimara") and opened to the public in 1987. It is located in a late 19th-century [neo-Renaissance](/wiki/Renaissance_Revival_architecture "Renaissance Revival architecture") palace.^[\[129\]](#cite_note-zageb_mim-132)^ The holdings comprise 3,750 works of art of various techniques and materials, and different cultures and civilizations, including paintings from great European masters like: [Caravaggio](/wiki/Caravaggio "Caravaggio"), [Raphael](/wiki/Raphael "Raphael"), [Pierre-Auguste Renoir](/wiki/Pierre-Auguste_Renoir "Pierre-Auguste Renoir"), [Rembrandt](/wiki/Rembrandt "Rembrandt"), [Hieronymus Bosch](/wiki/Hieronymus_Bosch "Hieronymus Bosch"), [Francisco Goya](/wiki/Francisco_Goya "Francisco Goya"), [Diego Velázquez](/wiki/Diego_Vel%C3%A1zquez "Diego Velázquez") and many others.{#cite_ref-zageb_mim_132-0}

The [Croatian Museum of Naïve Art](/wiki/Croatian_Museum_of_Na%C3%AFve_Art "Croatian Museum of Naïve Art") is one of the first museums of [naïve art](/wiki/Na%C3%AFve_art "Naïve art") in the world. The museum holds works of Croatian naïve expression of the 20th century. It is located in the 18th-century Raffay Palace in the [Gornji Grad](/wiki/Gornji_Grad_%E2%80%93_Medve%C5%A1%C4%8Dak "Gornji Grad – Medveščak"). The museum holdings consist of almost 2000 works of art -- paintings, sculptures, drawings, and prints, mainly by Croatians but also by other well-known world artists.^[\[130\]](#cite_note-zagreb_naïve-133)^ From time to time, the museum organizes topics and retrospective exhibitions by naïve artists, expert meetings and educational workshops and playrooms.{#cite_ref-zagreb_naïve_133-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/PSX_20190406_122459.jpg/220px-PSX_20190406_122459.jpg)](/wiki/File:PSX_20190406_122459.jpg) [Meštrović Pavilion](/wiki/Me%C5%A1trovi%C4%87_Pavilion "Meštrović Pavilion") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Msu-museum-contemporary-art-zagreb.jpg/220px-Msu-museum-contemporary-art-zagreb.jpg)](/wiki/File:Msu-museum-contemporary-art-zagreb.jpg) [Museum of Contemporary Art](/wiki/Museum_of_Contemporary_Art,_Zagreb "Museum of Contemporary Art, Zagreb")

The [Museum of Contemporary Art](/wiki/Museum_of_Contemporary_Art,_Zagreb "Museum of Contemporary Art, Zagreb") was founded in 1954. Its new building hosts a rich collection of Croatian and international contemporary visual art which has been collected throughout the decades from the nineteen-fifties until today. The museum is located in the center of [Novi Zagreb](/wiki/Novi_Zagreb "Novi Zagreb") and opened in 2009. The old location is now part of the Kulmer Palace in the [Gornji Grad](/wiki/Gornji_Grad_%E2%80%93_Medve%C5%A1%C4%8Dak "Gornji Grad – Medveščak").^[\[131\]](#cite_note-zagreb_contemporary-134)^{#cite_ref-zagreb_contemporary_134-0}

The Institute for Contemporary Art (*Institut za suvremenu umjetnost* ), successor to the Soros Center for Contemporary Art -- Zagreb (SCCA -- Zagreb), was founded in 1993, and registered as an independent nonprofit organization in 1998. It was founded and run by [art historians](/wiki/Art_historian "Art historian"), curators, artists, photographers, designers, publishers, academics, and journalists, and initially located at the Museum of Contemporary Art. After moving a number of times, the institute has a gallery at the Academia Moderna. Its aims are to promote contemporary Croatian artists and the [visual](/wiki/Visual_arts "Visual arts") and other creative arts; to start documenting contemporary artists; and to build a body of contemporary art. It established the Radoslav Putar Award in 2002.^[\[132\]](#cite_note-135)^{#cite_ref-135}

The [Strossmayer Gallery of Old Masters](/wiki/Strossmayer_Gallery_of_Old_Masters "Strossmayer Gallery of Old Masters") offers permanent holdings presenting European paintings from the 14th to 19th centuries,^[\[133\]](#cite_note-zageb_stross-136)^ and the [Ivan Meštrović](/wiki/Ivan_Me%C5%A1trovi%C4%87 "Ivan Meštrović") Studio, with sculptures, drawings, lithography portfolios and other items, was a donation of this great artist to his homeland. The Museum and Gallery Center introduces on various occasions the Croatian and foreign cultural and artistic heritage. The [Art Pavilion](/wiki/Art_Pavilion,_Zagreb "Art Pavilion, Zagreb") by Viennese architects Hellmer and Fellmer who were the most famous designers of theatres in Central Europe is a [neo-classical](/wiki/Neoclassicism "Neoclassicism") exhibition complex and one of the landmarks of the downtown. The exhibitions are also held in the Meštrović building on the [Square of the Victims of Fascism](/wiki/Square_of_the_Victims_of_Fascism "Square of the Victims of Fascism") -- the Home of Croatian Fine Artists. The World Center "Wonder of Croatian Naïve Art" exhibits masterpieces of Croatian naïve art as well as the works of a new generation of artists. The Modern Gallery comprises all relevant fine artists of the 19th and 20th centuries. The [Museum of Broken Relationships](/wiki/Museum_of_Broken_Relationships "Museum of Broken Relationships") at 2 Ćirilometodska holds people's mementos of past relationships.^[\[134\]](#cite_note-137)^^[\[135\]](#cite_note-138)^^[\[136\]](#cite_note-139)^ It is the first private museum in the country.^[\[137\]](#cite_note-140)^ [Lauba House](/wiki/Lauba_House "Lauba House") presents works from the [Filip Trade Collection](/wiki/Filip_Trade_Collection "Filip Trade Collection"), a large private collection of modern and contemporary Croatian art and current artistic production.^[\[138\]](#cite_note-141)^^[\[139\]](#cite_note-142)^{#cite_ref-142}  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8e/Botanical_garden_in_Zagreb_13.jpg/200px-Botanical_garden_in_Zagreb_13.jpg)](/wiki/File:Botanical_garden_in_Zagreb_13.jpg)  
[Zagreb Botanical Garden](/wiki/Zagreb_Botanical_Garden "Zagreb Botanical Garden").  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Lavlji_most_2.jpg/200px-Lavlji_most_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Lavlji_most_2.jpg)  
[Zagreb Zoo](/wiki/Zagreb_Zoo "Zagreb Zoo"), Lion's Bridge.

[Other museums and galleries](/wiki/List_of_museums_in_Croatia "List of museums in Croatia") are also found in the Croatian School Museum, the Croatian Hunting Museum, the Croatian Sports Museum, the Croatian Post and Telecommunications Museum, the HAZU ([Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts](/wiki/Croatian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts "Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts")) Glyptotheque (collection of monuments), and the HAZU Graphics Cabinet.

There are five [castles](/wiki/Castle "Castle") in Zagreb: Dvorac Brezovica, Kašina (Castrum antiquum Paganorum), Medvedgrad, Susedgrad and Kulmerovi dvori.^[\[140\]](#cite_note-143)^{#cite_ref-143}

[Zagreb Zoo](/wiki/Zagreb_Zoo "Zagreb Zoo") is a 7-hectare [Zoo](/wiki/Zoo "Zoo") located in [Maksimir Park](/wiki/Maksimir_Park "Maksimir Park"), opened in 1925 and it's one of the main attractions in Zagreb. The Zoo hold 2,225 animals of 275 species from all around the world. It's the most visited Zoo in Croatia with almost half of million visitors in 2023.^[\[141\]](#cite_note-144)^{#cite_ref-144}  

### Events {#Events}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Events")\]

Zagreb has hosted some of the most popular mainstream musical artists in recent years, including those of [Queen](/wiki/Queen_(band) "Queen (band)"), [Rolling Stones](/wiki/Rolling_Stones "Rolling Stones"), [U2](/wiki/U2 "U2"), [Guns N' Roses](/wiki/Guns_N%27_Roses "Guns N' Roses"), [Eric Clapton](/wiki/Eric_Clapton "Eric Clapton"), [Deep Purple](/wiki/Deep_Purple "Deep Purple"), [Bob Dylan](/wiki/Bob_Dylan "Bob Dylan"), [David Bowie](/wiki/David_Bowie "David Bowie"), [Elton John](/wiki/Elton_John "Elton John"), [Roger Waters](/wiki/Roger_Waters "Roger Waters"), [Depeche Mode](/wiki/Depeche_Mode "Depeche Mode"), [Prodigy](/wiki/The_Prodigy "The Prodigy"), [Beyoncé](/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9_Knowles "Beyoncé Knowles"), [Lady Gaga](/wiki/Lady_Gaga "Lady Gaga"), [Britney Spears](/wiki/Britney_Spears "Britney Spears"), [Ed Sheeran](/wiki/Ed_Sheeran "Ed Sheeran"), [Justin Bieber](/wiki/Justin_Bieber "Justin Bieber"), [Shakira](/wiki/Shakira "Shakira"), [Nick Cave](/wiki/Nick_Cave "Nick Cave"), [Jamiroquai](/wiki/Jamiroquai "Jamiroquai"), [George Michael](/wiki/George_Michael "George Michael"), [Sade](/wiki/Sade_(singer) "Sade (singer)"), [Sting](/wiki/Sting_(musician) "Sting (musician)"), [Rod Stewart](/wiki/Rod_Stewart "Rod Stewart"), [Eros Ramazzotti](/wiki/Eros_Ramazzotti "Eros Ramazzotti"), [Manu Chao](/wiki/Manu_Chao "Manu Chao"), [Massive Attack](/wiki/Massive_Attack "Massive Attack"), [Andrea Bocelli](/wiki/Andrea_Bocelli "Andrea Bocelli"), [Metallica](/wiki/Metallica "Metallica"), [50 Cent](/wiki/50_Cent "50 Cent"), [Snoop Dogg](/wiki/Snoop_Dogg "Snoop Dogg"), [Duran Duran](/wiki/Duran_Duran "Duran Duran") as well as some of world most recognised underground artists such as [Dimmu Borgir](/wiki/Dimmu_Borgir "Dimmu Borgir"), [Sepultura](/wiki/Sepultura "Sepultura"), [Melvins](/wiki/Melvins "Melvins"), [Mastodon](/wiki/Mastodon_(band) "Mastodon (band)") and more.

Zagreb is also the home of the [INmusic festival](/wiki/INmusic_festival "INmusic festival"), one of the biggest open-air festivals in Croatia which is held every year, usually at the end of June, hosting a lot of big names like [Hozier](/wiki/Hozier "Hozier"), [Lily Allen](/wiki/Lily_Allen "Lily Allen"), [Arctic Monkeys](/wiki/Arctic_Monkeys "Arctic Monkeys"), [Rokia Traoré](/wiki/Rokia_Traor%C3%A9 "Rokia Traoré"), [Anthrax](/wiki/Anthrax_(American_band) "Anthrax (American band)") and many more. There is also the Zagreb Jazz Festival which has featured popular jazz artists like [Pat Metheny](/wiki/Pat_Metheny "Pat Metheny") or [Sonny Rollins](/wiki/Sonny_Rollins "Sonny Rollins"). Many other festivals occur in Zagreb like Žedno uho featuring indie, rock, metal and electronica artists such as [Animal Collective](/wiki/Animal_Collective "Animal Collective"), [Melvins](/wiki/Melvins "Melvins"), [Butthole Surfers](/wiki/Butthole_Surfers "Butthole Surfers"), [Crippled Black Phoenix](/wiki/Crippled_Black_Phoenix "Crippled Black Phoenix"), [NoMeansNo](/wiki/NoMeansNo "NoMeansNo"), [The National](/wiki/The_National_(band) "The National (band)"), [Mark Lanegan](/wiki/Mark_Lanegan "Mark Lanegan"), [Swans](/wiki/Swans_(band) "Swans (band)"), [Mudhoney](/wiki/Mudhoney "Mudhoney") around the clubs and concert halls of Zagreb.  

### Performing arts {#Performing_arts}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Performing arts")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Croatian_National_Theatre_in_Zagreb_in_2018.jpg/220px-Croatian_National_Theatre_in_Zagreb_in_2018.jpg)](/wiki/File:Croatian_National_Theatre_in_Zagreb_in_2018.jpg) [Croatian National Theatre](/wiki/Croatian_National_Theatre_in_Zagreb "Croatian National Theatre in Zagreb") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Dvorana_Vatroslav_Lisinski_cijela_7_rujna_2008.jpg/220px-Dvorana_Vatroslav_Lisinski_cijela_7_rujna_2008.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dvorana_Vatroslav_Lisinski_cijela_7_rujna_2008.jpg) [Vatroslav Lisinski Concert Hall](/wiki/Vatroslav_Lisinski_Concert_Hall "Vatroslav Lisinski Concert Hall")

There are about 20 permanent or seasonal theatres and stages. The [Croatian National Theater in Zagreb](/wiki/Croatian_National_Theatre_in_Zagreb "Croatian National Theatre in Zagreb") was built in 1895 and opened by emperor [Franz Joseph I of Austria](/wiki/Franz_Joseph_I_of_Austria "Franz Joseph I of Austria"). The most renowned [concert hall](/wiki/List_of_concert_halls "List of concert halls") named "[Vatroslav Lisinski](/wiki/Vatroslav_Lisinski_Concert_Hall "Vatroslav Lisinski Concert Hall")", after the composer of the first Croatian opera, was built in 1973.

The [World Theatre Festival](/wiki/World_Theatre_Festival_(Zagreb) "World Theatre Festival (Zagreb)") and [International Puppet Festival](/wiki/International_Puppet_Festival "International Puppet Festival") both take place in Zagreb in September and October.^[\[142\]](#cite_note-zagrebfests-145)^{#cite_ref-zagrebfests_145-0}

*Animafest* , the World Festival of [Animated Films](/wiki/Animation "Animation"), takes place every even-numbered year, and the *Music Biennale* , the international festival of [avant-garde music](/wiki/Avant-garde_music "Avant-garde music"), every odd-numbered year. It also hosts the annual *[ZagrebDox](/wiki/ZagrebDox "ZagrebDox")* [documentary film](/wiki/Documentary_film "Documentary film") festival. The *Festival of the Zagreb [Philharmonic](/wiki/Orchestra "Orchestra")* and the flowers exhibition *Floraart* (end of May or beginning of June), the *Old-timer Rally* annual events. In the summer, theatre performances and concerts, mostly in the Upper Town, are organized either indoors or outdoors. The stage on Opatovina hosts the *Zagreb Histrionic Summer* theatre events.

Zagreb is also the host of *Zagrebfest* , the oldest Croatian [pop-music](/wiki/Pop_music "Pop music") [festival](/wiki/Music_festival "Music festival"), as well as of several traditional international sports events and tournaments. The *Day of the City of Zagreb* on 16 November is celebrated every year with special festivities, especially on the [Jarun](/wiki/Jarun "Jarun") lake in the southwestern part of the city.  

### Recreation and sports {#Recreation_and_sports}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Recreation and sports")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/Prva_vo%C5%BEnja_SQT2019_%C5%BEene.png/200px-Prva_vo%C5%BEnja_SQT2019_%C5%BEene.png)](/wiki/File:Prva_vo%C5%BEnja_SQT2019_%C5%BEene.png)  
[Snow Queen Trophy](/wiki/Snow_Queen_Trophy "Snow Queen Trophy") is a [World Cup](/wiki/FIS_Alpine_Ski_World_Cup "FIS Alpine Ski World Cup") [alpine ski](/wiki/Alpine_skiing "Alpine skiing") [race](/wiki/Racing "Racing") in Zagreb  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Jarun_20160702_5087.jpg/200px-Jarun_20160702_5087.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jarun_20160702_5087.jpg)  
[Arena Zagreb](/wiki/Arena_Zagreb "Arena Zagreb")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Jarun_Lake_aerial_view.jpg/200px-Jarun_Lake_aerial_view.jpg)](/wiki/File:Jarun_Lake_aerial_view.jpg)  
[Jarun Lake](/wiki/Jarun_Lake "Jarun Lake")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Zrinjevac_Park%2C_Zagreb%2C_Croatia_-_2022.jpg/200px-Zrinjevac_Park%2C_Zagreb%2C_Croatia_-_2022.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zrinjevac_Park,_Zagreb,_Croatia_-_2022.jpg)  
[Zrinjevac Park](/wiki/Zrinjevac_Park "Zrinjevac Park")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2b/Maksimir_20151101_DSC_3621.JPG/200px-Maksimir_20151101_DSC_3621.JPG)](/wiki/File:Maksimir_20151101_DSC_3621.JPG)  
[Maksimir Park](/wiki/Maksimir_Park "Maksimir Park")

Zagreb is home to numerous sports and recreational centers. Recreational [Sports Center](/wiki/SportsCenter "SportsCenter") Jarun, situated on [Jarun Lake](/wiki/Jarun "Jarun") in the southwest of the city, has fine shingle beaches, a world-class [regatta](/wiki/Regatta "Regatta") course, a [jogging](/wiki/Jogging "Jogging") lane around the lake, several restaurants, many [night clubs](/wiki/Nightclub "Nightclub") and a [discothèque](/wiki/Discoth%C3%A8que "Discothèque"). Its sports and recreation opportunities include swimming, sunbathing, waterskiing, angling, and other [water sports](/wiki/List_of_water_sports "List of water sports"), but also [beach volleyball](/wiki/Beach_volleyball "Beach volleyball"), football, basketball, handball, table tennis, and [mini-golf](/wiki/Miniature_golf "Miniature golf").
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0c/Zicara_za_inficu.jpg/170px-Zicara_za_inficu.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zicara_za_inficu.jpg) The newly opened [Zagreb cable car](/wiki/Zagreb_cable_car "Zagreb cable car")

[Dom Sportova](/wiki/Dom_Sportova "Dom Sportova"), a sport centre in northern [Trešnjevka](/wiki/Tre%C5%A1njevka "Trešnjevka") features six halls. The largest two have seating capacity of 5,000 and 3,100 people, respectively.^[\[143\]](#cite_note-146)^ This centre is used for basketball, handball, volleyball, hockey, gymnastics, tennis, etc. It also hosts music events.{#cite_ref-146}

[Arena Zagreb](/wiki/Arena_Zagreb "Arena Zagreb") was finished in 2008. The 16,500-seat arena^[\[144\]](#cite_note-147)^ hosted the [2009 World Men's Handball Championship](/wiki/2009_World_Men%27s_Handball_Championship "2009 World Men's Handball Championship"). The [Dražen Petrović Basketball Hall](/wiki/Dra%C5%BEen_Petrovi%C4%87_Basketball_Hall "Dražen Petrović Basketball Hall") seats 5,400 people. Alongside the hall is the 94 m (308 ft) high glass [Cibona Tower](/wiki/Cibona_Tower "Cibona Tower"). [Sports Park Mladost](/wiki/Mladost_(sports_society) "Mladost (sports society)"), situated on the embankment of the Sava river, has an [Olympic-size swimming pool](/wiki/Olympic-size_swimming_pool "Olympic-size swimming pool"), smaller indoor and outdoor swimming pools, a sunbathing terrace, 16 tennis courts as well as [basketball](/wiki/Basketball "Basketball"), [volleyball](/wiki/Volleyball "Volleyball"), [handball](/wiki/Team_handball "Team handball"), [football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football") and [field hockey](/wiki/Field_hockey "Field hockey") courts. A volleyball sports hall is within the park. Sports and Recreational Center Šalata, located in [Šalata](/wiki/%C5%A0alata "Šalata"), only a couple hundred meters from the [Jelačić Square](/wiki/Ban_Jela%C4%8Di%C4%87_Square "Ban Jelačić Square"), is most attractive for tennis players. It comprises a big [tennis court](/wiki/Tennis_court "Tennis court") and eight smaller ones, two of which are covered by the so-called "balloon", and another two equipped with lights. The center also has swimming pools, basketball courts, football fields, a gym, and fitness center, and a four-lane [bowling](/wiki/Bowling "Bowling") alley. Outdoor [ice skating](/wiki/Ice_skating "Ice skating") is a popular winter recreation. There are also several fine restaurants within and near the center.{#cite_ref-147}

Maksimir Tennis Center, located in Ravnice east of [downtown](/wiki/Donji_grad_(Zagreb) "Donji grad (Zagreb)"), consists of two sports blocks. The first comprises a tennis center situated in a large tennis hall with four courts. There are 22 outdoor tennis courts with lights. The other block offers multipurpose sports facilities: apart from tennis courts, there are handball, basketball and [indoor football](/wiki/Indoor_soccer "Indoor soccer") grounds, as well as [track and field](/wiki/Track_and_field "Track and field") facilities, a [bocce ball](/wiki/Bocce "Bocce") alley and [table tennis](/wiki/Table_tennis "Table tennis") opportunities.

Recreational swimmers can enjoy a smaller-size indoor swimming pool in Daničićeva Street, and a newly opened indoor Olympic-size pool at [Utrine](/wiki/Utrine,_Zagreb "Utrine, Zagreb") sports center in Novi Zagreb. Skaters can skate in the [skating rink](/wiki/Ice_rink "Ice rink") on Trg Sportova (Sports Square) and on the lake Jarun Skaters' park. [Zagreb Hippodrome](/wiki/Zagreb_Hippodrome "Zagreb Hippodrome") offers recreational [horseback riding](/wiki/Equestrianism "Equestrianism") opportunities, while [horse races](/wiki/Horse_racing "Horse racing") are held every weekend during the warmer part of the year.

The 38,923^[\[145\]](#cite_note-148)^-seat [Maksimir Stadium](/wiki/Stadion_Maksimir "Stadion Maksimir"), last 10 years under renovation, is located in [Maksimir](/wiki/Maksimir "Maksimir") in the northeastern part of the city. The stadium is part of the immense Svetice recreational and sports complex (ŠRC Svetice), south of the Maksimir Park. The complex covers an area of 276,440 m^2^ (68 acres). It is part of a significant green zone, which passes from [Medvednica](/wiki/Medvednica "Medvednica") in the north toward the south. ŠRC Svetice, together with Maksimir Park, creates an ideal connection of areas which are assigned to sport, recreation, and leisure.{#cite_ref-148}

The latest larger recreational facility is [Bundek](/wiki/Bundek "Bundek"), a group of two small lakes near the Sava in [Novi Zagreb](/wiki/Novi_Zagreb "Novi Zagreb"), surrounded by a partly forested park. The location had been used prior to the 1970s, but then went to neglect until 2006 when it was renovated.

In year 2021 Zagreb was the host city of [Croatia Rally](/wiki/Croatia_Rally "Croatia Rally"), round three of [2021 World Rally Championship](/wiki/2021_World_Rally_Championship "2021 World Rally Championship"). The Rally was won by [Sébastien Ogier](/wiki/S%C3%A9bastien_Ogier "Sébastien Ogier") and [Julien Ingrassia](/wiki/Julien_Ingrassia "Julien Ingrassia"), [Toyota Gazoo Racing WRT](/wiki/Toyota_Gazoo_Racing_WRT "Toyota Gazoo Racing WRT") crew. Service parc, Overnight parc ferme and Shakedown [Medvedgrad](/wiki/Medvedgrad "Medvedgrad") took place in Zagreb placing him as a lone capital in the championship. [2021 Croatia Rally](/wiki/2021_Croatia_Rally "2021 Croatia Rally") became third tightest WRC event up to date, with only 0,6 seconds dividing the winning crew and second placed [Elfyn Evans](/wiki/Elfyn_Evans "Elfyn Evans") and [Scott Martin (co-driver)](/wiki/Scott_Martin_(co-driver) "Scott Martin (co-driver)") in Toyota Yaris WRC. The Croatian round of WRC was praised by becoming the part of [2022 World Rally Championship](/wiki/2022_World_Rally_Championship "2022 World Rally Championship").

Some of the most notable sport clubs in Zagreb are: [GNK Dinamo Zagreb](/wiki/GNK_Dinamo_Zagreb "GNK Dinamo Zagreb"), [KHL Medveščak Zagreb](/wiki/KHL_Medve%C5%A1%C4%8Dak_Zagreb "KHL Medveščak Zagreb"), [RK Zagreb](/wiki/RK_Zagreb "RK Zagreb"), [KK Cibona](/wiki/KK_Cibona "KK Cibona"), [KK Zagreb](/wiki/KK_Zagreb "KK Zagreb"), [KK Cedevita](/wiki/KK_Cedevita "KK Cedevita"), [NK Zagreb](/wiki/NK_Zagreb "NK Zagreb"), [HAVK Mladost](/wiki/HAVK_Mladost "HAVK Mladost") and others. The city hosted the [2016 Davis Cup World Group](/wiki/2016_Davis_Cup_World_Group "2016 Davis Cup World Group") final between [Croatia](/wiki/Croatia_Davis_Cup_team "Croatia Davis Cup team") and [Argentina](/wiki/Argentina_Davis_Cup_team "Argentina Davis Cup team").  

### Religion {#Religion}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Religion")\]  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Blick_auf_die_Kathedrale_von_Zagreb.jpg/192px-Blick_auf_die_Kathedrale_von_Zagreb.jpg)](/wiki/File:Blick_auf_die_Kathedrale_von_Zagreb.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/Mirogoj_Cemetery%2C_Zagreb_03.jpg/192px-Mirogoj_Cemetery%2C_Zagreb_03.jpg)](/wiki/File:Mirogoj_Cemetery,_Zagreb_03.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/05/Z%C3%A1h%C5%99eb%2C_pravoslavn%C3%BD_chr%C3%A1m_4.jpg/192px-Z%C3%A1h%C5%99eb%2C_pravoslavn%C3%BD_chr%C3%A1m_4.jpg)](/wiki/File:Z%C3%A1h%C5%99eb,_pravoslavn%C3%BD_chr%C3%A1m_4.jpg)  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Zagreb_-_Islamski_centar_-_d%C5%BEamija.jpg/192px-Zagreb_-_Islamski_centar_-_d%C5%BEamija.jpg)](/wiki/File:Zagreb_-_Islamski_centar_-_d%C5%BEamija.jpg)  
Clockwise from top left: [Zagreb Cathedral](/wiki/Zagreb_Cathedral "Zagreb Cathedral"), [Church of Christ the King in Mirogoj](/wiki/Mirogoj_Cemetery "Mirogoj Cemetery"), [Zagreb Mosque](/wiki/Zagreb_Mosque "Zagreb Mosque") and [Serbian Orthodox Church Cathedral](/wiki/Serbian_Orthodox_Cathedral,_Zagreb "Serbian Orthodox Cathedral, Zagreb") with statue of [Petar Preradović](/wiki/Petar_Preradovi%C4%87 "Petar Preradović")

The [Archdiocese of Zagreb](/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_Zagreb "Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Zagreb") is a [metropolitan see](/wiki/Metropolitan_bishop "Metropolitan bishop") of the [Catholic Church in Croatia](/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Croatia "Roman Catholicism in Croatia"), serving as its religious center. The Archbishop is [Dražen Kutleša](/wiki/Dra%C5%BEen_Kutle%C5%A1a "Dražen Kutleša"). The Catholic Church is the largest religious organisation in Zagreb, Catholicism being the predominant religion of Croatia, with over 1.1 million adherents.^[\[146\]](#cite_note-149)^ Zagreb is also the [Episcopal see](/wiki/Episcopal_see "Episcopal see") of the [Metropolitanate of Zagreb and Ljubljana](/wiki/Metropolitanate_of_Zagreb_and_Ljubljana "Metropolitanate of Zagreb and Ljubljana") of the [Serbian Orthodox Church](/wiki/Eastern_Orthodoxy_in_Croatia "Eastern Orthodoxy in Croatia"). [Islamic religious organization of Croatia](/wiki/Islam_in_Croatia "Islam in Croatia") has the see in Zagreb. President is Mufti Aziz Hasanović. There used to be a mosque in the [Meštrović Pavilion](/wiki/Me%C5%A1trovi%C4%87_Pavilion "Meštrović Pavilion") during [World War II](/wiki/Zagreb_in_World_War_II "Zagreb in World War II")^[\[147\]](#cite_note-150)^ at the [Square of the Victims of Fascism](/wiki/Square_of_the_Victims_of_Fascism "Square of the Victims of Fascism"), but it was relocated to the neighborhood of Borovje in [Peščenica](/wiki/Pe%C5%A1%C4%8Denica_%E2%80%93_%C5%BDitnjak "Peščenica – Žitnjak"). Mainstream Protestant churches have also been present in Zagreb -- Evangelical (Lutheran) Church and Reformed Christian (Calvinist) Church. [The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints](/wiki/The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints "The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints") (LDS Church) is also present in the Zagreb neighborhood of [Jarun](/wiki/Jarun "Jarun") whereas Jehovah's Witnesses have their headquarters in Central Zagreb.^[\[148\]](#cite_note-151)^ In total there are around 40 non-Catholic religious organizations and denominations in Zagreb with their headquarters and places of worship across the city making it a large and diverse multicultural community. There is also significant [Jewish history](/wiki/History_of_the_Jews_in_Croatia "History of the Jews in Croatia") through [the Holocaust](/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia "The Holocaust in the Independent State of Croatia").{#cite_ref-151}  

Economy {#Economy}
------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Economy")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Z%C3%A1h%C5%99eb_budova_%C5%99editelstv%C3%AD_H%C5%BD_3.jpg/220px-Z%C3%A1h%C5%99eb_budova_%C5%99editelstv%C3%AD_H%C5%BD_3.jpg)](/wiki/File:Z%C3%A1h%C5%99eb_budova_%C5%99editelstv%C3%AD_H%C5%BD_3.jpg) [Croatian Railways](/wiki/Croatian_Railways "Croatian Railways") headquarters

Important branches of industry are: production of electrical machines and devices, [chemical](/wiki/Chemical_industry "Chemical industry"), [pharmaceutical](/wiki/Pharmaceutical_drug "Pharmaceutical drug"), [textile](/wiki/Textile_industry "Textile industry"), [food and drink](/wiki/Food_industry "Food industry") processing. Zagreb is an [international trade](/wiki/International_trade "International trade") and business centre, as well as an essential transport hub placed at the crossroads of Central Europe, the Mediterranean and the [Southeast Europe](/wiki/Southeast_Europe "Southeast Europe").^[\[149\]](#cite_note-zageb_economy-152)^ Almost all of the largest Croatian as well as Central European companies and conglomerates such as [Agrokor](/wiki/Agrokor "Agrokor"), [INA](/wiki/INA_(company) "INA (company)"), [Hrvatski Telekom](/wiki/Hrvatski_Telekom "Hrvatski Telekom") have their headquarters in the city.{#cite_ref-zageb_economy_152-0}

The only Croatian stock exchange is the Zagreb Stock Exchange ([Croatian](/wiki/Croatian_language "Croatian language"): *Zagrebačka burza* ), which is located in [Eurotower](/wiki/Eurotower_(Zagreb) "Eurotower (Zagreb)"), one of the tallest [Croatian skyscrapers](/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_Croatia "List of tallest buildings in Croatia").

According to 2008 data, the city of Zagreb has the highest PPP and nominal [gross domestic product](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product") per capita in Croatia at $32,185 and $27,271 respectively, compared to the Croatian averages of US$18,686 and $15,758.^[\[150\]](#cite_note-zagreb_stat-153)^{#cite_ref-zagreb_stat_153-0}
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1d/Hrvatska_Narodna_Banka.jpg/220px-Hrvatska_Narodna_Banka.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hrvatska_Narodna_Banka.jpg) [Croatian National Bank](/wiki/Croatian_National_Bank "Croatian National Bank") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Viktor_Kova%C4%8Di%C4%87_-_Pala%C4%8Da_burze_u_Zagrebu_-_kupola_-_20231104_130753.jpg/220px-Viktor_Kova%C4%8Di%C4%87_-_Pala%C4%8Da_burze_u_Zagrebu_-_kupola_-_20231104_130753.jpg)](/wiki/File:Viktor_Kova%C4%8Di%C4%87_-_Pala%C4%8Da_burze_u_Zagrebu_-_kupola_-_20231104_130753.jpg) Dome of the Zagreb Old Stock Exchange Palace [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/58/HGK_zgrada.jpg/220px-HGK_zgrada.jpg)](/wiki/File:HGK_zgrada.jpg) [Croatian Chamber of Economy](/wiki/Croatian_Chamber_of_Economy "Croatian Chamber of Economy")

As of May 2015, the average monthly net salary in Zagreb was 6,669 [kuna](/wiki/Croatian_kuna "Croatian kuna"), about [€](/wiki/Euro "Euro")870 (Croatian average is 5,679 kuna, about €740).^[\[151\]](#cite_note-154)^^[\[152\]](#cite_note-155)^ At the end of 2012, the average [unemployment](/wiki/Unemployment "Unemployment") rate in Zagreb was around 9.5%.^[\[153\]](#cite_note-156)^ 34% of companies in Croatia have headquarters in Zagreb, and 38.4% of the Croatian workforce works in Zagreb, including almost all banks, utility and public transport companies.^[\[154\]](#cite_note-157)^^[\[155\]](#cite_note-158)^^[\[156\]](#cite_note-159)^{#cite_ref-159}

Companies in Zagreb create 52% of the total turnover and 60% of the total profit of Croatia in 2006 as well as 35% of Croatian export and 57% of Croatian import.^[\[157\]](#cite_note-hgk_ppp-160)^^[\[158\]](#cite_note-161)^ The following table includes some of the main economic indicators for the period 2011--2019, based on the data provided by the [Croatian Bureau of Statistics](/wiki/Croatian_Bureau_of_Statistics "Croatian Bureau of Statistics").^[\[159\]](#cite_note-dzs_bdp_2022-162)^^[\[160\]](#cite_note-BDP_NUTS_Regions_2023-163)^ A linear interpolation was used for the population data between 2011 and 2021. Transport {#Transport}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=30 "Edit section: Transport")\]  
Main article: [Transport in Zagreb](/wiki/Transport_in_Zagreb "Transport in Zagreb")  

### Highways {#Highways}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Highways")\]  
Further information: [Highways in Croatia](/wiki/Highways_in_Croatia "Highways in Croatia")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/37/Zagrebacki_prsten.png/250px-Zagrebacki_prsten.png)](/wiki/File:Zagrebacki_prsten.png) [Zagreb bypass](/wiki/Zagreb_bypass "Zagreb bypass") existing and planned routes

Zagreb is the hub of five major Croatian highways.

The highway [A6](/wiki/A6_(Croatia) "A6 (Croatia)") was upgraded in October 2008 and leads [from Zagreb to Rijeka](/wiki/A7_(Croatia)#Route_description "A7 (Croatia)"), forming a part of the Pan-European Corridor Vb. The upgrade coincided with the opening of the [bridge over the Mura river](/wiki/Zrinski_Bridge "Zrinski Bridge") on the [A4](/wiki/A4_(Croatia) "A4 (Croatia)") and the completion of the Hungarian [M7](/wiki/M7_motorway_(Hungary) "M7 motorway (Hungary)"), which marked the opening of the first freeway corridor between [Rijeka](/wiki/Rijeka "Rijeka") and [Budapest](/wiki/Budapest "Budapest").^[\[162\]](#cite_note-arz-165)^ The [A1](/wiki/A1_(Croatia) "A1 (Croatia)") starts at the [Lučko interchange](/wiki/Lu%C4%8Dko_interchange "Lučko interchange") and [concurs](/wiki/Concurrency_(road) "Concurrency (road)") with the A6 up to the [Bosiljevo 2 interchange](/wiki/Bosiljevo_2_interchange "Bosiljevo 2 interchange"), connecting Zagreb and [Split](/wiki/Split,_Croatia "Split, Croatia") (As of October 2008^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit)^ [Vrgorac](/wiki/Vrgorac "Vrgorac")). A further extension of the A1 up to [Dubrovnik](/wiki/Dubrovnik "Dubrovnik") is under construction^\[*[needs update](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")*\]^. Both highways are tolled by the Croatian highway authorities [Hrvatske autoceste](/wiki/Hrvatske_autoceste "Hrvatske autoceste") and [Autocesta Rijeka - Zagreb](/wiki/Autocesta_Rijeka_-_Zagreb "Autocesta Rijeka - Zagreb").^\[*[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")*\]^{#cite_ref-arz_165-0}

Highway [A3](/wiki/A3_(Croatia) "A3 (Croatia)") (formerly named [Bratstvo i jedinstvo](/wiki/Brotherhood_and_unity "Brotherhood and unity")) was the showpiece of Croatia in the [SFRY](/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia "Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia"). It is the oldest Croatian highway.^[\[163\]](#cite_note-bratstvo-enotnost-166)^^[\[164\]](#cite_note-RTS-vremeplov-167)^ A3 forms a part of the [Pan-European Corridor X](/wiki/Pan-European_Corridor_X "Pan-European Corridor X"). The highway starts at the [Bregana](/wiki/Bregana "Bregana") [border crossing](/wiki/Border_checkpoint "Border checkpoint"), bypasses Zagreb forming the southern arch of the [Zagreb bypass](/wiki/Zagreb_bypass "Zagreb bypass"), and ends at [Lipovac](/wiki/Lipovac,_Vukovar-Srijem_County "Lipovac, Vukovar-Srijem County") near the Bajakovo border crossing. It continues in [Southeast Europe](/wiki/Southeast_Europe "Southeast Europe") in the direction of [Near East](/wiki/Near_East "Near East"). This highway is tolled except for the stretch between Bobovica and [Ivanja Reka](/wiki/Ivanja_Reka_interchange "Ivanja Reka interchange") interchanges.^[\[165\]](#cite_note-HAC-A3-prospekt-168)^{#cite_ref-HAC-A3-prospekt_168-0}

Highway [A2](/wiki/A2_(Croatia) "A2 (Croatia)") is a part of the [Corridor Xa](/wiki/Pan-European_Corridor_Xa "Pan-European Corridor Xa").^[\[166\]](#cite_note-corridors-169)^ It connects Zagreb and the frequently congested [Macelj](/wiki/Macelj "Macelj") border crossing, forming a near-continuous motorway-level link between Zagreb and [Western Europe](/wiki/Western_Europe "Western Europe").^[\[167\]](#cite_note-2000loan-170)^ Forming a part of the Corridor Vb, highway [A4](/wiki/A4_(Croatia) "A4 (Croatia)") starts in Zagreb forming the northeastern wing of the [Zagreb bypass](/wiki/Zagreb_bypass "Zagreb bypass") and leads to Hungary until the [Goričan](/wiki/Gori%C4%8Dan "Goričan") border crossing. It is often used highway around Zagreb.^[\[168\]](#cite_note-171)^{#cite_ref-171}

The railway and the highway [A3](/wiki/A3_(Croatia) "A3 (Croatia)") along the [Sava](/wiki/Sava "Sava") river that extend to [Slavonia](/wiki/Slavonia "Slavonia") (towards [Slavonski Brod](/wiki/Slavonski_Brod "Slavonski Brod"), [Vinkovci](/wiki/Vinkovci "Vinkovci"), [Osijek](/wiki/Osijek "Osijek") and [Vukovar](/wiki/Vukovar "Vukovar")) are some of the busiest traffic corridors in the country.^[\[169\]](#cite_note-zageb_tran-172)^ The railway running along the [Sutla](/wiki/Sutla "Sutla") river and the [A2](/wiki/A2_(Croatia) "A2 (Croatia)") highway (Zagreb-[Macelj](/wiki/Macelj "Macelj")) running through [Zagorje](/wiki/Zagora_(Croatia) "Zagora (Croatia)"), as well as traffic connections with the Pannonian region and Hungary (the [Zagorje](/wiki/Hrvatsko_Zagorje "Hrvatsko Zagorje") railroad, the roads and railway to [Varaždin](/wiki/Vara%C5%BEdin "Varaždin") -- [Čakovec](/wiki/%C4%8Cakovec "Čakovec") and [Koprivnica](/wiki/Koprivnica "Koprivnica")) are linked with truck routes.^[\[170\]](#cite_note-hž-173)^ The southern railway connection to [Split](/wiki/Split,_Croatia "Split, Croatia") operates on a high-speed [tilting trains](/wiki/Tilting_train "Tilting train") line via the [Lika](/wiki/Lika "Lika") region (renovated in 2004 to allow for a five-hour journey); a faster line along the [Una](/wiki/Una_(Sava) "Una (Sava)") river valley is in use only up to the border between Croatia and [Bosnia and Herzegovina](/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Bosnia and Herzegovina").^[\[170\]](#cite_note-hž-173)^^[\[171\]](#cite_note-vjesnik_tilting_trains-174)^{#cite_ref-vjesnik_tilting_trains_174-0}  

### Roads {#Roads}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=32 "Edit section: Roads")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2d/%C4%8Cvor_Lu%C4%8Dko_iz_zraka.jpg/200px-%C4%8Cvor_Lu%C4%8Dko_iz_zraka.jpg)](/wiki/File:%C4%8Cvor_Lu%C4%8Dko_iz_zraka.jpg) Part of the [Zagreb bypass](/wiki/Zagreb_bypass "Zagreb bypass"), Lučko interchange is the Zagreb's gateway to the [Adriatic coast](/wiki/Adriatic_coast "Adriatic coast") [![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5a/Antunovic_hotel_-_Zagreb_%2815322254719%29.jpg/200px-Antunovic_hotel_-_Zagreb_%2815322254719%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Antunovic_hotel_-_Zagreb_(15322254719).jpg) [Zagrebačka Avenue](/wiki/Zagreba%C4%8Dka_Avenue "Zagrebačka Avenue")

The city has an extensive [avenue](/wiki/Boulevard "Boulevard") network with numerous main arteries up to ten lanes wide and [Zagreb bypass](/wiki/Zagreb_bypass "Zagreb bypass"), a congested four-lane [highway](/wiki/Highway "Highway") encircling most of the city. Finding a parking space is supposed to be made somewhat easier by the construction of new underground multi-story parking lots (Importanne Center, Importanne Gallery, Lang Square, Tuškanac, Kvaternik Square, Klaić Street, etc.). The busiest roads are the main east--west arteries, former [Highway "Brotherhood and Unity"](/wiki/Brotherhood_and_Unity_Highway "Brotherhood and Unity Highway"), consisting of [Ljubljanska Avenue](/wiki/Ljubljanska_Avenue "Ljubljanska Avenue"), [Zagrebačka Avenue](/wiki/Zagreba%C4%8Dka_Avenue "Zagrebačka Avenue") and [Slavonska Avenue](/wiki/Slavonska_Avenue "Slavonska Avenue"); and the Vukovarska Avenue, the closest bypass of the city center. The avenues were supposed to alleviate the traffic problem, but most of them are nowadays gridlocked during rush hour and others, like Branimirova Avenue and Dubrovnik Avenue which are gridlocked for the whole day.^[\[172\]](#cite_note-175)^^[\[173\]](#cite_note-176)^^[\[174\]](#cite_note-177)^ [European routes](/wiki/International_E-road_network "International E-road network") [E59](/wiki/European_route_E59 "European route E59"), [E65](/wiki/European_route_E65 "European route E65") and [E70](/wiki/E70_in_Croatia "E70 in Croatia") serve Zagreb.{#cite_ref-177}  

#### Bridges {#Bridges}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=33 "Edit section: Bridges")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Domovinski_most_Zg_0907.JPG/200px-Domovinski_most_Zg_0907.JPG)](/wiki/File:Domovinski_most_Zg_0907.JPG) [Homeland Bridge](/wiki/Homeland_Bridge "Homeland Bridge")

Zagreb has seven road traffic bridges across the [river Sava](/wiki/Sava "Sava"), and they all span both the river and the [levees](/wiki/Levee "Levee"), making them all by and large longer than 200 m (660 ft). In downstream order, these are:
{#cite_ref-Crnobrnja_178-0}

|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|--------------------|----------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|

| **[Adriatic Bridge](/wiki/Adriatic_Bridge "Adriatic Bridge")**              | *Jadranski most*   | 1981                 | Six lane road bridge (also carries [tram](/wiki/Tram "Tram") tracks)                                                    | [Adriatic Avenue](/wiki/Adriatic_Sea "Adriatic Sea")                          | The most famous bridge in Zagreb. The bridge spans from Savska Street in the north to the [Remetinec Roundabout](/wiki/Remetinec_Roundabout "Remetinec Roundabout") in the south.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                         |

The bridge is known among experts due to some construction details.^[\[175\]](#cite_note-Crnobrnja-178)^                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      |
| **[Liberty Bridge](/wiki/Liberty_Bridge,_Zagreb "Liberty Bridge, Zagreb")** | *Most slobode*     | 1959                 | Four lane road bridge                                                                                                   | [Većeslav Holjevac Avenue](/wiki/Ve%C4%87eslav_Holjevac "Većeslav Holjevac")  | It used to hold a pair of [bus lanes](/wiki/Bus_lane "Bus lane"), but due to the increasing individual traffic and better tram connections across the river, those were converted to normal lanes.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                        |
| **[Youth Bridge](#Bridges)**                                                | *Most mladosti*    | 1974                 | Six lane road bridge (also carries tram tracks)                                                                         | [Marin Držić Avenue](/wiki/Marin_Dr%C5%BEi%C4%87_Avenue "Marin Držić Avenue") | Connects eastern [Novi Zagreb](/wiki/Novi_Zagreb "Novi Zagreb") to the districts of [Trnje](/wiki/Trnje,_Zagreb "Trnje, Zagreb"), [Peščenica](/wiki/Pe%C5%A1%C4%8Denica_%E2%80%93_%C5%BDitnjak "Peščenica – Žitnjak"), [Donja Dubrava](/wiki/Donja_Dubrava,_Zagreb "Donja Dubrava, Zagreb") and [Maksimir](/wiki/Maksimir "Maksimir").                                                                                                                                                    |
| **[Homeland Bridge](/wiki/Homeland_Bridge "Homeland Bridge")**              | *Domovinski most*  | 2007                 | Four-lane road bridge (also carries two bicycle and two pedestrian lanes; has space reserved for light railroad tracks) | [Radnička (Workers') Road](/wiki/Workforce "Workforce")                       | This bridge is the last bridge built on the Sava river to date; it links [Peščenica](/wiki/Pe%C5%A1%C4%8Denica_%E2%80%93_%C5%BDitnjak "Peščenica – Žitnjak") via Radnička street to the [Zagreb bypass](/wiki/Zagreb_bypass "Zagreb bypass") at Kosnica. It is planned to continue towards [Zagreb Airport](/wiki/Zagreb_Airport "Zagreb Airport") at [Pleso](/wiki/Pleso "Pleso") and [Velika Gorica](/wiki/Velika_Gorica "Velika Gorica"), and on to state road D31 going to the south. |

There are also two rail traffic bridges across the Sava, one near the Sava bridge and one near [Mičevec](/wiki/Mi%C4%8Devec "Mičevec"), as well as two bridges that are part of the [Zagreb bypass](/wiki/Zagreb_bypass "Zagreb bypass"), one near [Zaprešić](/wiki/Zapre%C5%A1i%C4%87 "Zaprešić") (west), and the other near [Ivanja Reka](/wiki/Ivanja_Reka "Ivanja Reka") (east).

Two additional bridges across the river [Sava](/wiki/Sava "Sava") are proposed: Jarun Bridge and Bundek Bridge.  

### Public transportation {#Public_transportation}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=34 "Edit section: Public transportation")\]
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/19-06-16-Zagreb-DJI_0183.jpg/225px-19-06-16-Zagreb-DJI_0183.jpg)](/wiki/File:19-06-16-Zagreb-DJI_0183.jpg) [Main Railway Station](/wiki/Zagreb_Glavni_kolodvor "Zagreb Glavni kolodvor")

[Public transportation](/wiki/Public_transport "Public transport") in the city is organized in several layers: the inner parts of the city are mostly covered by [trams](/wiki/Tram "Tram"), the outer city areas, and closer suburbs are linked with buses and rapid transit [commuter rail](/wiki/Zagreb_Commuter_Rail "Zagreb Commuter Rail").

The public transportation company [ZET](/wiki/Zagreba%C4%8Dki_elektri%C4%8Dni_tramvaj "Zagrebački električni tramvaj") (*Zagrebački električni tramvaj*, Zagreb Electric Tram) operates trams, all inner bus lines, and most of the suburban bus lines, and it is subsidized by the city council.

The national rail operator [Croatian Railways](/wiki/Croatian_Railways "Croatian Railways") (*Hrvatske željeznice* , HŽ) runs a network of urban and suburban train lines in the metropolitan Zagreb area and is a [government-owned corporation](/wiki/Government-owned_corporation "Government-owned corporation").

The [funicular](/wiki/Funicular "Funicular") (*uspinjača* ) in the historic part of the city is a [tourist attraction](/wiki/Tourist_attraction "Tourist attraction").

[Taxi](/wiki/Taxicab "Taxicab") market has been liberalized in early 2018^[\[176\]](#cite_note-179)^ and numerous transport companies have been allowed to enter the market. Consequently, the prices significantly dropped whereas the service was immensely improved so the popularity of taxis in Zagreb has been increasing.{#cite_ref-179}  

#### Tram network {#Tram_network}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=35 "Edit section: Tram network")\]  
Main article: [Trams in Zagreb](/wiki/Trams_in_Zagreb "Trams in Zagreb")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/A_Crotram_TMK_2200_at_Glavni_Kolodvor.jpg/200px-A_Crotram_TMK_2200_at_Glavni_Kolodvor.jpg)](/wiki/File:A_Crotram_TMK_2200_at_Glavni_Kolodvor.jpg)  
[Trams in Zagreb](/wiki/Trams_in_Zagreb "Trams in Zagreb")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/ZG_train_and_tram.jpg/200px-ZG_train_and_tram.jpg)](/wiki/File:ZG_train_and_tram.jpg)  
[Zagreb Commuter Rail](/wiki/Zagreb_Commuter_Rail "Zagreb Commuter Rail")

Zagreb has an extensive [tram](/wiki/Tram "Tram") network with 15 day and 4 night lines covering much of the inner- and middle-suburbs of the city. The first tram line was opened on 5 September 1891 and trams have been serving as a vital component of Zagreb mass transit ever since. Trams usually travel at speeds of 30--50 km/h (19--31 mph), but slow considerably during [rush hour](/wiki/Rush_hour "Rush hour"). On narrower streets the tracks are either shared with car traffic or separated by a painted yellow line, which can still be used by taxis, buses and emergency vehicles, whereas on larger avenues the tracks are situated inside [green belts](/wiki/Reserved_track "Reserved track").

An ambitious program, which entailed replacing old trams with the new and modern ones built mostly in Zagreb by companies [Končar elektroindustrija](/wiki/KON%C4%8CAR_Group "KONČAR Group") and, to a lesser extent, by [TŽV Gredelj](/wiki/T%C5%BDV_Gredelj "TŽV Gredelj"), has recently been finished. The new "[TMK 2200](/wiki/CROTRAM "CROTRAM")", trams by the end of 2012 made around 95% of the fleet.^[\[177\]](#cite_note-new_series-180)^{#cite_ref-new_series_180-0}  

#### Suburban rail network {#Suburban_rail_network}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=36 "Edit section: Suburban rail network")\]  
Main article: [Zagreb Commuter Rail](/wiki/Zagreb_Commuter_Rail "Zagreb Commuter Rail")

The commuter rail network in Zagreb has existed since 1992. In 2005, suburban rail services were increased to a 15-minute frequency serving the middle and outer suburbs of Zagreb, primarily in the east--west direction and to the southern districts. This has enhanced the commuting opportunities across the city.^[\[178\]](#cite_note-suburban_rail-181)^{#cite_ref-suburban_rail_181-0}

A new link to the nearby town of [Samobor](/wiki/Samobor "Samobor") has been announced and is due to start construction in 2014. This link will be [standard-gauge](/wiki/Standard_gauge "Standard gauge") and tie in with normal [Croatian Railways](/wiki/Croatian_Railways "Croatian Railways") operations. The previous narrow-gauge line to Samobor called *[Samoborček](/wiki/Samobor%C4%8Dek "Samoborček")* was closed in the 1970s.^[\[179\]](#cite_note-samoborček-182)^{#cite_ref-samoborček_182-0}  

### Air traffic {#Air_traffic}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=37 "Edit section: Air traffic")\]  
Main article: [Zagreb Airport](/wiki/Zagreb_Airport "Zagreb Airport")
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Inside_Zagreb_airpot_july_2017.jpg/200px-Inside_Zagreb_airpot_july_2017.jpg)](/wiki/File:Inside_Zagreb_airpot_july_2017.jpg) [Franjo Tuđman Airport Zagreb](/wiki/Zagreb_Airport "Zagreb Airport") new passenger terminal

[Zagreb Airport](/wiki/Zagreb_Airport "Zagreb Airport") ([IATA](/wiki/IATA_airport_code "IATA airport code"): **ZAG** , [ICAO](/wiki/ICAO_airport_code "ICAO airport code"): **LDZA** ) is the main Croatian international airport, a 17 km (11 mi) drive southeast of Zagreb in the city of [Velika Gorica](/wiki/Velika_Gorica "Velika Gorica"). The airport is also the main Croatian airbase featuring a fighter squadron, helicopters, as well as military and freight [transport aircraft](/wiki/Cargo_aircraft "Cargo aircraft").^[\[180\]](#cite_note-zageb_pleso-183)^ The airport had 3.45 million passengers in 2019 with a new passenger terminal being opened in late March 2017 that can accommodate up to 5.5 million passengers.{#cite_ref-zageb_pleso_183-0}

Zagreb also has a second, smaller airport, [Lučko](/wiki/Lu%C4%8Dko "Lučko") ([ICAO](/wiki/ICAO_airport_code "ICAO airport code"): **LDZL** ). It is home to sports aeroplanes and a Croatian special police unit, as well as being a military helicopter airbase. Lučko used to be the main airport of Zagreb from 1947 to 1959.^[\[181\]](#cite_note-184)^{#cite_ref-184}

A third, small grass airfield, Buševec, is located just outside [Velika Gorica](/wiki/Velika_Gorica "Velika Gorica"). It is primarily used for sports purposes.^[\[182\]](#cite_note-buševec-185)^{#cite_ref-buševec_185-0}  

Education {#Education}
----------------------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Education")\]

Zagreb has 136 [primary](/wiki/Primary_education "Primary education") schools and 100 [secondary](/wiki/Secondary_education "Secondary education") schools including 30 [gymnasia](/wiki/Gymnasium_(school) "Gymnasium (school)").^[\[183\]](#cite_note-mzos_prim_ed-186)^^[\[184\]](#cite_note-mzos_sec_ed-187)^ There are 5 public [higher education](/wiki/Higher_education "Higher education") institution and 9 private professional higher education schools.^[\[185\]](#cite_note-mzos_higher_ed-188)^{#cite_ref-mzos_higher_ed_188-0}

There are 4 International Schools in Zagreb:^[\[186\]](#cite_note-189)^{#cite_ref-189}

* American International School of Zagreb (AISZ)
* The Learning Tree International Kindergarten (TLT)
* French School in Zagreb
* The German School in Zagreb.^[\[187\]](#cite_note-190)^{#cite_ref-190}

### University of Zagreb {#University_of_Zagreb}

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit&section=39 "Edit section: University of Zagreb")\]  
Main article: [University of Zagreb](/wiki/University_of_Zagreb "University of Zagreb")  
Further information: [List of universities in Croatia](/wiki/List_of_universities_in_Croatia "List of universities in Croatia")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/PMF_%C5%A0alata_Zagreb.jpg/160px-PMF_%C5%A0alata_Zagreb.jpg)](/wiki/File:PMF_%C5%A0alata_Zagreb.jpg)  
[Faculty of Science, University of Zagreb](/wiki/Faculty_of_Science,_University_of_Zagreb "Faculty of Science, University of Zagreb")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Academia_Croata_de_Ciencias_y_Artes%2C_Zagreb%2C_Croacia%2C_2014-04-20%2C_DD_01.JPG/230px-Academia_Croata_de_Ciencias_y_Artes%2C_Zagreb%2C_Croacia%2C_2014-04-20%2C_DD_01.JPG)](/wiki/File:Academia_Croata_de_Ciencias_y_Artes,_Zagreb,_Croacia,_2014-04-20,_DD_01.JPG)  
[Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts](/wiki/Croatian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts "Croatian Academy of Sciences and Arts")  
[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/National_and_University_Library_in_Zagreb.jpg/160px-National_and_University_Library_in_Zagreb.jpg)](/wiki/File:National_and_University_Library_in_Zagreb.jpg)  
[National and University Library](/wiki/National_and_University_Library_in_Zagreb "National and University Library in Zagreb")

Founded in 1669, the University of Zagreb is the oldest continuously operating university in Croatia and one of the largest^[\[188\]](#cite_note-191)^^[\[189\]](#cite_note-192)^^[\[190\]](#cite_note-193)^^[\[191\]](#cite_note-194)^^[\[192\]](#cite_note-195)^^[\[193\]](#cite_note-196)^ and oldest universities in the Southeastern Europe. Ever since its foundation, the university has been continually growing and developing and now consists of 29 faculties, three art academies and the Croatian Studies Centre. More than 200,000 students have attained the [Bachelor's degree](/wiki/Bachelor%27s_degree "Bachelor's degree") at the university, which has also assigned 18,000 [Master's](/wiki/Master%27s_degree "Master's degree") and 8,000 [Doctor's degrees](/wiki/Doctorate "Doctorate").^[\[194\]](#cite_note-zg_brief-197)^ As of 2011^[\[update\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Zagreb&action=edit)^, the University of Zagreb is ranked among 500 Best Universities of the world by the Shanghai Academic Ranking of World Universities.{#cite_ref-zg_brief_197-0}

Zagreb is the seat of two private universities: the [Catholic University of Croatia](/wiki/Catholic_University_of_Croatia "Catholic University of Croatia") and the Libertas International University. It also hosts numerous public and private polytechnics, colleges and higher professional schools.^\[*[which?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Avoid_weasel_words "Wikipedia:Avoid weasel words")*\]^
